Stesichorus and Aeschylus had deeply impressed this on the Greek mind; and it would have been hard for Athenians, familiar with the lyric and the dramatic Oresteia, to feel that the story, as told by Sophocles, reached a true conclusion. His Chorus might, indeed, close the play by describing the house of Atreus as

Ï„á¿‡ Î½á¿¦Î½ á½ÏÎ¼á¿‡ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ‰Î¸á½³Î½.

But would not many spectators have ringing in their ears the last words of the Choephori?

Ï€Î¿á¿– Î´á¿†Ï„Î± ÎºÏÎ±Î½Îµá¿–, Ï€Î¿á¿– ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î»á½µÎ¾ÎµÎ¹ Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î¹ÏƒÎ¸á½²Î½ Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï„Î·Ï‚;

Character of Electra.

Ï„Î¿Ïƒá½¹Î½Î´â€™ á¼Ï‚ á¼¥Î²Î·Ï‚, Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¶ Ï„Î¹Î¼Ï‰Ïá½¸Î½ Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…. ğŸ—©
Line 14

The Sophoclean Electra resembles Antigone in heroism and in loyalty to the dead, but the modes in which their characters are manifested differ as widely as the situations. Antigone is suddenly required to choose between omitting a sacred duty and incurring death; within a day she has chosen, and died. The ordeal of Electra is that of maintaining a solitary protest through years of suffering. Her timid sister's sympathy is only secret; the tyrants ill-treat her, and she witnesses their insults to her father's memory. Meanwhile there is only one feeble ray of light for her, the hope that Orestes may return; but it becomes fainter as time goes on. One of the finest traits in the delineation of Electra by Sophocles is the manner in which he suggests that inward life of the imagination into which she has shrunk back from the world around her. To her, the dead father is an ally ever watchful to aid the retribution; when she hears of Clytaemnestra's dream, it at once occurs to her that he has helped to send itVv. 459, 460.. The youthful Orestes, as her brooding fancy pictures him, is already invested with the heroic might of an avengerVv. 1220 f. Electra (to the disguised Orestes), Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Îµá¼¶Ï€Î±Ï‚, á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿–; Î¿Ï€.ÏˆÎµá¿¦Î´Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ <*>Î½ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰. | Î—Î›. á¼¦ Î¶á¿‡ Î³á½°Ï á¼Î½á½µÏ; . There are moments when she can almost forget her misery in visions of his triumphSee on v. 814.. Like Antigone, she is contrasted with a weaker, though amiable, sister. Chrysothemis is of the same type as Ismene; her instincts are right, and respond to the appeal of Electra, whom she loves; only she is not heroic. The stronger nature, when brought into conflict with the feebler, almost inevitably assumes, at certain moments, an aspect of harshnessVv. 391; 1027 ff. Cp. Introduction to the Antigone, p. xxix.: yet the union in Electra of tenderness with strength can be felt throughout, and finds expression in more than one passage of exquisite beautySee especially the kommos, 823â€”870; and her lament, 1126â€”1170.. When she believes that Orestes is dead, and that it rests with her alone to avenge Agamemnon, she calls upon Chrysothemis to co-operate, who reproves her as forgetting that she is a woman997 Î³Ï…Î½á½´ Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼€Î½á½´Ï á¼”Ï†Ï…Ï‚.. But when Orestes is restored to her, she submits herself in all things to his wishes1301 ff. 4 Electra played the chief part in another play also of Sophocles,â€”the á¼ˆÎ»á½µÏ„Î·Ï‚, to which Attius was probably indebted in his Agamemnonidae and Erigona. A sketch of the plot is conjecturally recognised in Hyginus Fab. 122.Aletes, son of Aegisthus, sends Electra a false message to the effect that Orestes (who is in exile) is dead, and that Aletes therefore accedes to the throne at Mycenae. Electra goes to consult the oracle at Delphi. She there meets a woman who (she is told) has slain Orestes; and is about to blind her with a brand snatched from the altar, when Orestes rushes between themâ€”reveals himselfâ€”and tells her that the woman is her sister Iphigeneia. Orestes slays Aletes, whose daughter Erigona goes to Attica; and Pylades marries Electra. (Cp. Roscher, Lex.p. 1238.) The time supposed in the á¼ˆÎ»á½µÏ„Î·Ï‚ was apparently just after the year of exile (á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„Î¹ÏƒÎ¼á½¹Ï‚ï¼‰ imposed upon Orestes by the slaying of his mother. Here, then (as in the presence of Iphigeneia), would be proof that in his Aletes the poet followed a different conception of the story from that which he adopts in his Electra.. Hers is the part which Aeschylus gives to the Chorus, of speaking with Aegisthus on his way to the house. She is present almost from the beginning to the end of the play, and the series of her emotions is the thread which gives unity to the whole.

15 Î½á¿¦Î½ Î¿á½–Î½, á½ˆÏá½³ÏƒÏ„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½º Ï†á½·Î»Ï„Î±Ï„Îµ Î¾á½³Î½Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 15

The cause which she holds sacred is elaborately ar- Clytaemnestra. raigned and defended in the scene with Clytaemnestra. Sophocles portrays the queen in a manner very distinct from that of Aeschylus; a difference due not merely to the general tendencies of the poets, but also to the dramatic setting. Aeschylus created his Clytaemnestra in the Agamemnon, where she is seen just before and just after the murder. There is a fascination in her dreadful presence of mind; what an adamantine purpose can be felt under the fluent eloquence with which she welcomes her husband Ag. 855â€”913.! How fearful, again, is her exultation in the deed, when she tells the Argive elders that she rejoices in the blood upon her robe â€˜as a cornfield in the dews of springib. 1390 ff.,â€™ or when she imagines Iphigeneia advancing to greet Agamemnon in the shades, and kissing himib. 1555 ff.! Sophocles had to show Clytaemnestra, not at a crisis of action, but as she lived and felt in the years which followed her crime. Electra's fortitude was to be illustrated by withstanding and denouncing her. The Clytaemnestra of Aeschylus was ill-suited to such a situation. If she had been confronted with a daughter who impugned her deed, scorn and hatred would have flashed from her; but she would not have argued her case in detail, and then listened to a reply. The almost superhuman force of that dark soul would have been fatal to the dramatic effect of any woman opposed to her. In the Choephori Aeschylus has taken care that Electra shall have no dialogue with Clytaemnestra. Sophocles clearly felt this. The Clytaemnestra whom he draws is strong and wicked, but her temperament is not one which separates her from ordinary humanity. She feels at least a pang of maternal grief when she first hears that Orestes is dead El. 766 ff. Contrast her hypocritical rhetoric at the corresponding moment in Aesch. Cho. 691 ff., even though a little later she can address heartless taunts to Electra. She has not the Aeschylean queen's cynical contempt for public opinion; thus she complains that Electra misrepresents her, and seeks to justify herself Soph. El. 520 ff.. When she meets her daughter in argument, she is forcible, but the better cause has the advantage which it deservesib. 516â€”609.. A desire to avenge Iphigeneia is the plea which she puts forward, and which Electra refutes; but the women of Mycenae had already given voice to the popular belief that guilty love was the true motive of the crimeib. 197 Î´á½¹Î»Î¿Ï‚ <*>Î½ á½ Ï†Ïá½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, á¼”ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á½ ÎºÏ„Îµá½·Î½Î±Ï‚.. Sophocles has thus avoided investing Clytaemnestra with a tragic interest which would have required that her punishment, rather than her paramour's, should form the climax.

The Chorus.The function of the Chorus is naturally to some extent the same as in the Choephori,â€”viz., to sympathise with Electra and to assert the moral law: but there is a difference. The Trojan slave-women of the Aeschylean Chorus hate the tyrants and are friendly to Electra's cause, but have no further interest in the vengeance. The Sophoclean Chorus consists of freeborn women, belonging to Mycenae, but external to the palace. They represent a patriotic sentiment in the realm at large, favourable to the son of Agamemnon, and hostile to the usurper. The city is sympathetic with the familyCp. the words of the Chorus in v. 1413, á½¦ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚, á½¦ Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá½° Îº.Ï„.Î». In v. 1227 Electra addresses them as Ï€Î¿Î»á½·Ï„Î¹Î´ÎµÏ‚. Their feeling towards Orestes as the heir is seen in 160 ff.: cp. too 251 ff. (n.)..

Î Ï…Î»á½±Î´Î·, Ï„á½· Ï‡Ïá½´ Î´Ïá¾¶Î½ á¼Î½ Ï„á½±Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÏ…Ï„á½³Î¿Î½Â· ğŸ—©
Line 16

While the strictly human interest predominates in the Supernatural agency Electra, we must not undervalue the dramatic importance which Sophocles has given to the supernatural agency, or the skill with which it is carried through the texture of the play. In the opening scene we hear the oracle which Apollo has given to Orestes. The enterprise is presently placed under the protection of the Chthonian powers by those ceremonies at the tomb which, as the old man urges, must precede everything else. Then Electra comes forth, and invokes the deities of the underworld. A little later it appears that Clytaemnestra has had an ominous dream; Electra sees in it an answer to her prayer, and the Chorus express the same conviction. Next, the queen makes her offerings and half-secret prayers to Apollo; the very god, though she knows it not, who has already sent Orestes home. With a similar unconsciousness, in her joy at the news from Phocis, she declares that Nemesis has heard those who deserved to be heard, and has ordained aright. The last act. of Orestes and Pylades before entering the house is to salute the images of the gods; while Electra makes a short prayer to Apollo. Lastly, in the moments of suspense before the deed, the choral song reminds us that the Erinyes have passed beneath the roof, and that Hermes is guiding the avenger to the goal.

Thus the whole drama is pervaded by an under-current of divine co-operation; the gods are silently at work; step by step the irresistible allies advance; the very effort of Clytaemnestra to bespeak Apollo's favour is a new impiety, which only makes his wrath more certain. In the Choephori darkness broods over all; the shadow of the curse rests upon the murderers, and then the menace of the Erinyes comes upon the avenger. In the Electra of Sophocles it is the bright influence of Apollo that prevails from the first. Those sights and sounds of early morning with which the play opens are fit symbols of his presence; the powers of the nether world are also, indeed, active, but here they are making common cause with the Pythian god of light and purity.

The Electra of Euripides.

á½¡Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á½¶Î½ á¼¤Î´Î· Î»Î±Î¼Ï€Ïá½¸Î½ á¼¡Î»á½·Î¿Ï… Ïƒá½³Î»Î±Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 17

Let us now see how the subject is treated by Euripides.

The scene is laid before the cottage of a husbandman, or small farmer (Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï…ÏÎ³á½¹Ï‚), who lives in Argolis, but near the borders (v. 96), and far from the city of Argos (v. 246). The time is dawn.

Analysis. I. Prologue: 1â€” 166. (1) 1st scene, 1â€” 53.The play is opened by a speech of the farmer. Aegisthus and Clytaemnestra have given him Electra in marriage; fearing that, if she wedded a richerEuripides seeks to soften the strangeness of the alliance by vv. 37 f., where the Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï…ÏÎ³á½¹Ï‚ says that his â€˜Mycenaean fathers,â€™ though poor, were Î»Î±Î¼Ï€ÏÎ¿á½¶ á¼Ï‚ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. No doubt the invention of the Î±á½Ï„Î¿Ï…ÏÎ³á½¹Ï‚ was primarily suggested to the poet's mind by his feeling that Aeschylus had violated probability when he made Orestes adventure himself in the lion's (or wolf's) den, by going to the palace. But, if Orestes was not to do that, his meeting with Electra could be managed only by fixing her abode somewhere else, at a safe distance from the palace; and how was this to be done? spouse, he or his offspring might avenge Agamemnon. The worthy man adds that respect for the family has forbidden him to regard the union as more than formalVv. 43 ff.: á¼£Î½ Î¿á½”Ï€Î¿Î¸â€™ á¼Î½á½´Ï á½…Î´Îµ, Ïƒá½»Î½Î¿Î¹Î´á½³ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Îšá½»Ï€ÏÎ¹Ï‚, | á¾”ÏƒÏ‡Ï…Î½ÎµÎ½ Îµá½Î½á¿‡Â· Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼”Ï„â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶ Î´á½µ. | Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î³á½°Ï á½€Î»Î²á½·Ï‰Î½ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î± | Î»Î±Î²á½¼Î½ á½‘Î²Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½, Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Î¾Î¹Î¿Ï‚ Î³ÎµÎ³á½½Ï‚..

(2) 2nd scene, 54 â€”81.Electra comes out of the cottage, poorly clad, with her hair cut short (in sign of mourning), and bearing a water-jar upon her head. She is not forced, she says, to do these menial tasks, but she wishes to show the insolence of Aegisthus to the gods (v. 58). The farmer deprecates such work for her, and she expresses her grateful esteem for him. Then she goes on her way to the spring, and he to his plough.

(3) 3rd scene, 82 â€”166.Orestes enters, with PyladesThough Pylades is with him, Orestes is not supposed to come, directly at least, from Crisa; he is a wandering exile (233 f.), on whose head Aegisthus has set a price (v. 33). (who is a mute person throughout). An oracle of Apollo (he says) has sent him. He does not dare to go within the walls of the city. But in the night he has secretly sacrificed at Agamemnon's tomb, and has placed a lock of hair upon it. He has now come to find Electra, of whose marriage he has heard, and to seek her co-operation. â€”He now sees a woman, apparently a slave, approaching, and proposes to seek information from her. This is Electra, returning with her water-jar from the spring. In a lyric lament she speaks of Agamemnon's fate and her brother's exile. Orestes, listening, soon learns who she is, for she introduces her own name.

The Chorus enters. It consists of fifteen maidens from Parodos: 167â€”212. the neighbourhood, who hold a lyric dialogue with Electra. They invite her to a festival of the Argive Hera, but she excuses herself, on the ground of her sorrow, and also of her poor attire. They offer to lend her better clothes, but she replies by reminding them of the unavenged wrongs which she is mourningThis Parodos has been made famous by the story in Lysander 15. After the surrender of Athens in the spring of 404 B.C., the Peloponnesian leaders were deliberating on its fate, when they chanced to hear this ode sung, and were softened towards the city which had produced such a poet. (Ï€Î±Ïá½° Ï€á½¹Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï„Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ Î¦Ï‰Îºá½³Ï‰Ï‚ á¾„ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼Îº Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î•á½ÏÎ¹Ï€á½·Î´Î¿Ï… á¼¨Î»á½³ÎºÏ„ÏÎ±Ï‚ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Î´Î¿Î½, á¼¢Ï‚ á¼¡ á¼€ÏÏ‡á½´ á¼ˆÎ³Î±Î¼á½³Î¼Î½Î¿Î½Î¿Ï‚ á½¦ Îºá½¹ÏÎ±..., Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹ÎºÎ»Î±ÏƒÎ¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ Îº.Ï„.Î».ï¼‰.

Electra now perceives that two armed strangers are near her II. First episode: 213â€”431. (1) 1st scene, 213 â€”340. cottage, and is disquieted. Orestes does not reveal himself, but says that he has come to bring her news of her brother. Having heard his tidings, she speaks of her own fortunes. If Orestes returned, she would help him to slay their mother (vv. 278 f.). She describes how Aegisthus insults Agamemnon's tomb, and mocks at Orestes.

The farmer now reappears, and is somewhat disconcerted (2) 2nd scene, 341 â€”431. at first, but quickly recovers himself, and gracefully offers hospitality to the strangers. Orestes accepts the invitation, after moralising on the nobility of nature which may lurk under a rustic exterior. The two guests having gone in, Electra reproves her husband for having invited them, when he knew the poverty of the household. He must now go, she says, and look for a certain old man in the neighbourhood, who is capable of bringing some better fare for the visitors. This old man, it seems, had been an attendant of Agamemnon when the latter was a boy (v. 409). The farmer obeys, and goes forthâ€”to be seen no more.

<*> staslmon: 432 â€”486.The Chorus sing of the voyage of the Greek heroes to Troy, and the shield of Achilles. They end with imprecations upon Clytaemnestra, who slew the leader of such a host.

III. Second episode: 487â€”698. (1) 1st scene, 487 â€”552.The old retainer of Agamemnon, for whom the farmer went, now arrives, bringing lamb, cheeses, and some good wine for the guests; but, though he can provide these comforts, he is clad, after Euripidean fashion, in rags (v. 501).

On his way he has visited Agamemnon's tomb, and has been surprised by finding recent offerings there. One of these, a lock of hair, he brings with him, and suggests that, since it is like Electra's, it may be from the head of Orestes. She ridicules his surmise; and here follows the well-known satire on the other signs used by Aeschylus for the â€˜recognitionEur. El. 524â€”544. The fact that two locks of hair are á½Î¼á½¹Ï€Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î¹â€”by which she means, â€˜of the same colourâ€™â€”is, she reminds him, no proof of kinship. When he suggests that she should go and see whether the footprints tally with her own, she observes that (1) the soil is too hard to receive a footprint, and (2) a brother's foot is likely to be larger than his sister's. When he lastly suggests that Orestes may have a garment woven for him long ago by his sister, she replies that by this time it must be much too small for him. Dr Verrall (Choephori, pp. xxxv ff.) thinks that the meaning of Aeschylus was subtler than that fixed upon him by Euripides. (1) The resemblance between the hair of Orestes and that of Electra was not in colour merely, but in some Asiatic quality by which the foreign race of Pelops could be distinguished from Achaeans. (2) So as to the footprints: the resemblance meant was not in size, but in the character of the outline. (3) The á½”Ï†Î±ÏƒÎ¼Î± was not a garment, but a small specimen of Electra's work which the brother had with him. Euripides himself seems to make a slip here. Electra reproves the old man for suggesting that Orestes would have deigned, through fear of Aegisthus, to conceal his visit to the tomb (524â€”526). That, however, is what Orestes had done (90)..â€™

(2) 2nd scene, 553 â€”595.Orestes and Pylades come out of the cottage. Electra introduces the old man to the strangers as one who formerly saved her brother's life. The old man recognises Orestes by a scar over one eyebrow (v. 573), caused by a fall in childhood, when he and Electra were chasing a fawn. The joy of the recognition is compressed into very narrow limits; but the Chorus sings a short ode (vv. 585â€”595).

(3) 3rd scene, 596 â€”698.Orestes now consults the old man as to a scheme of vengeance. It would be impossible (says the old man) for Orestes to enter the guarded stronghold of the usurpers (615 ff.). But Aegisthus is now in the country, about to sacrifice to the Nymphs. He has no guards with him,â€”only servants. Orestes must present himself at the sacrifice, and take his chance of being asked to assist. Clytaemnestra is at Argos. But Electra undertakes to send her a message which will bring her to the cottage (v. 652). It was customary that, ten days after the birth of a child, offerings should be made to Eileithyia. The old man must tell Clytaemnestra that her daughter entreats this pious office at her hands, as she herself is unacquainted with the ritual (v. 1125).

The old man promises to take this message. He will also guide Orestes to Aegisthus. The brother and sister pray to the gods. Electra then enters the house, while Orestes sets forth with his guide.

The Chorus recite the legend of the golden lamb, the cause Second stasimon: 699â€”746. IV. Third episode: 747â€” 1146. (1) 1st scene, 747 â€”958. of the quarrel between Atreus and Thyestes.

A messenger tells Electra how Orestes has slain Aegisthus. The tyrant welcomed the youth and his comrade (Pylades), who described themselves as Thessalians going to Olympia. Orestes was asked to assist in dismembering a bull; and, while Aegisthus was stooping to scan the omens, felled him from behind. The slaves, on hearing the name of Orestes, acclaimed him as their rightful king.

The Chorus and Electra express their joy. Orestes enters (v. 880) with a ghastly trophyâ€”the bodyM. Patin doubts this, Sophocle, p. 355. But it is proved by v. 959 (Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ Ïƒá¿¶Î¼)), and by 1178 ff. á¼´Î´ÎµÏ„Îµ...Î´á½·Î³Î¿Î½Î± Ïƒá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î±. of Aegisthus, carried by attendants. Electra expresses her hatred in a long speech over the corpse (vv. 907â€”956).

Clytaemnestra now approaches from Mycenae (v. 963), in a (2) 2nd scene, 959 â€”1146. chariot, with a retinue. Orestes is seized with shuddering at the thought of slaying his mother. Electra nerves him; reminds him of his duty to his father, and of Apollo's oracle. He enters the cottageâ€”resolved to do the deed, and yet shrinking from it.

The Chorus briefly greet Clytaemnestra with pretended reverence. She bids her Trojan handmaids assist her to alight, but Electra claims the office, remarking that she herself is virtually a slave. Then follows a dispute between mother and daughter as to the fate of Iphigeneia and of Agamemnon (1011â€”1099). But the queen is presently touched by Electra's misery, and expresses regret for the past. Electra, however, is not softened. Then Clytaemnestra enters the house, to perform the rite on behalf of the (supposed) child. Electra bids her be careful that in the smoky cottage her robes are not soiledâ€”and presently follows her in (v. 1146).

Kommos: 1147â€” 1237.The Chorus recall the death of Agamemnon, and foretell the vengeance. In the midst of their chant, Clytaemnestra's dying shriek is heard from within.

Orestes and Electra are now shown (by the eccyclema) standing by the corpse of Clytaemnestra; that of Aegisthus lies near.

Orestes is full of anguish and despair. He describes how he drew his cloak over his eyes as he slew his mother. Electra, on the contrary, is in this scene almost a Lady Macbeth. She tells how she urged her brother on, and even guided his sword when he covered his eyes1224 f. Î—Î›. á¼Î³á½¼ Î´á½³ Î³â€™ á¼Ï€ÎµÎºá½³Î»ÎµÏ…Ïƒá½± ÏƒÎ¿Î¹, | Î¾á½·Ï†Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„â€™ á¼Ï†Î·Ïˆá½±Î¼Î·Î½ á¼…Î¼Î±.. Then she throws a covering over her mother's body.

Exodos: 1238â€” 1359.At this moment the Chorus greet the apparition of two bright forms in the air. These are the Dioscuri. Clytaemnestra, they say, has been justly slain, and yet Orestes is defiled. Apollo gave him an unwise oracle; though, as that god is their superior, they will say no more1245 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼„Î½Î±Î¾ Î³á½±Ï á¼ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚, | ÏƒÎ¹Î³á¿¶Â· ÏƒÎ¿Ï†á½¸Ï‚ Î´â€™ á½¢Î½ Î¿á½Îº á¼”Ï‡ÏÎ·Ïƒá½³ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ ÏƒÎ¿Ï†á½±.. Electra is to marry Pylades, and go to Phocisâ€”taking with her the good farmer, who is to receive a large estate (v. 1287). Orestes is to go to Athens, where, under the presidency of Pallas, he will be tried and acquitted; he will then settle in Arcadia1273 f. Ïƒá½² Î´â€™ á¼ˆÏÎºá½±Î´Ï‰Î½ Ï‡Ïá½´ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Î½ á¼Ï€â€™ á¼ˆÎ»Ï†ÎµÎ¹Î¿á¿¦ á¿¥Î¿Î±á¿–Ï‚ | Î¿á¼°ÎºÎµá¿–Î½ Î›Ï…ÎºÎ±á½·Î¿Ï… Ï€Î»Î·Ïƒá½·Î¿Î½ ÏƒÎ·Îºá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚. The city meant is Tegea, where there was a temple of Zeus Î›Ï…ÎºÎ±á¿–Î¿Ï‚, and where the supposed relics of Orestes were found ( Her. 1. 68).. Aegisthus will be buried by the Argives; Clytaemnestra, by MenelaÃ¼s and Helen, who have just arrived at Nauplia from Egypt.

1292â€” 1359.The play ends with a most curious dialogue in anapaests between the Dioscuri and the other persons. The Chorus bluntly ask the demigods why they did not avert murder from their sister Clytaemnestra? Well, they reply, the blame rests on Fate, and on the unwise utterances of Phoebus1302 Î¦Î¿á½·Î²Î¿Ï… Ï„â€™ á¼„ÏƒÎ¿Ï†Î¿Î¹ Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚ á¼Î½Î¿Ï€Î±á½·.. Electra then asks why sheâ€”to whom no oracle had been givenâ€”was involved in the guilt of matricide? The only answer which occurs to them is that she suffers through the hereditary curse upon the whole house of Pelops1305 ff. ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½Î±á½¶ Ï€Ïá½±Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½Î¿á½¶ Î´á½² Ï€á½¹Ï„Î¼Î¿Î¹Â· | Î¼á½·Î± Î´â€™ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï„á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚ | á¼„Ï„Î· Ï€Î±Ï„á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ Î´Î¹á½³ÎºÎ½Î±Î¹ÏƒÎµÎ½.. Orestes changes the awkward subject by taking leave of Electra, whom he is not to see again. The Dioscuri have words of comfort for each. And then they warn Orestes to hasten away; already dark forms can be seen approaching, with snaky arms1345 Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Î´Ïá½±ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, Ï‡Ïá¿¶Ï„Î± ÎºÎµÎ»Î±Î¹Î½Î±á½·. This description of the Erinyes is exactly illustrated by a vase-painting given in Baumeister's DenkmÃ¤ler p. 1116. They grasp the snakes, which are coiled round their arms, near the head, so that snake and arm are, as it were, one.. The Dioscuri themselves â€˜will go with speed to the Sicilian sea, to save the ships1347 ff. The play was probably produced at the great Dionysia of March, 413 B.C..â€™

á¼‘á¿·Î± ÎºÎ¹Î½Îµá¿– Ï†Î¸á½³Î³Î¼Î±Ï„â€™ á½€ÏÎ½á½·Î¸Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÎ±Ï†á¿† ğŸ—©
Line 18

It is in this closing scene, where the Dioscuri are cross- Drift of Euripides â€”adverse to Apollo. examined, that the drift of Euripides is most patent. The dialogue is equivalent to an epilogue by the dramatist, who, in effect, addresses the audience as follows:â€”â€˜I have now told you this story in my own wayâ€”adhering to the main lines of the tradition, but reconciling it, as far as possible, with reason. And now, having done my best with it, I feel bound to add that it remains a damning indictment against Apollo, and a scandal to the moral sense of mankind.â€™

Euripides could not relieve Orestes from the guilt of matri- His Orestes and Electra. cide; tradition forbad; but he has sought to modify that guilt. He has divided the responsibility between Orestes and Electra in such a manner as to make the sister appear the more coldblooded of the two. It is she who plans the snare into which her mother falls. While Orestes wavers and falters, Electra never hesitates for a moment. She unflinchingly bears her part in the murder, when her brother is fain to cover his eyes while he strikes. Yet (as is brought out in the dialogue with the Dioscuri) she had not his excuse. No oracle had been given to her. Her ruling motive appears as an inflexible hatred of her mother. The Electra of the two other dramatists has in deed that feeling, but the noble and gentle side of her character is far more prominentThe Electra of Sophocles, standing outside of the house, hears the shriek of Clytaemnestra, whom Orestes is at that moment slaying within; and exclaims, Ï€Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¿Î½, Îµá¼° ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¿†Î½ (v. 1415). That is, to modern feeling, the most repellent trait which Sophocles has given to her. But it is as nothing in comparison with the part which the Euripidean Electra bears in the actual deed; and it is also an isolated utterance at a moment of extreme tension.. The general result, then, is this:â€” Euripides gives up Apollo, who told Orestes to commit matricide, as indefensible; while, by a skilful contrast with a more odious person, he contrives to increase our commiseration for Orestes, the hapless instrument of the god.

General estimate of the play.The play was unduly depreciated by Schlegel, and a reaction has long since made itself feltAmong the earlier exponents of this reaction may be mentioned Hartung (Euripides restitutus, vol. II. pp. 305 ff.), and HalÃ©vy (GrÃ¨ce Tragique, vol. I. pp. 90 ff.). See also Patin, Sophocle, p. 340.. Yet a critic who is second to none, either in appreciation for the genius of Euripides or in power of interpreting it,â€”Professor von Wilamowitz-MÃ¶llendorff,â€”has said that, when one passes from Aeschylus to the Euripidean Electra, it is like turning from Goethe to Heine, â€”not merely to a less elevated strain, but rather to a wholly different tone,â€”sordid, trivial, and (from a Greek point of view) blasphemousHermes, vol. XVIII. p. 233. Es ist als kÃ¤me man von Goethe zu Heine, als lÃ¤se man nicht sowohl eine geringere Poesie, als eine Umsetzung ins Meskine Frivole Blasphemische.. We may recognise to the utmost the bold originality of Euripides, the inventive power, and the skilful execution; but his Electra, viewed as a Greek tragedy, cannot be pronounced a success.

Did it precede and influence the Electra of Sophocles?

Î¼á½³Î»Î±Î¹Î½á½± Ï„â€™ á¼„ÏƒÏ„ÏÏ‰Î½ á¼ÎºÎ»á½³Î»Î¿Î¹Ï€ÎµÎ½ Îµá½Ï†Ïá½¹Î½Î·. ğŸ—©
Line 19

It has hitherto been generally held that the Electra of Sophocles belongs to an earlier date than its Euripidean namesake. A contrary view is however maintained by v. Wilamowitz, who further thinks that the Electra of Euripides was the stimulus which moved Sophocles to treat the subjectHermes, vol. XVIII. pp. 214â€”263: Die beiden Elektren.. Certain relations (the able critic contends) exist between the two plays which show that one of them was influenced by the other, and a closer scrutiny proves that the play of Euripides was the original. I propose to examine this view.

The first resemblance to which the critic points is between The openings of the two plays compared. the openings of the two dramas. In the Euripidean prologue Orestes appears and speaks (vv. 82â€”111). Then Electra sings a monody (112â€”166); and she is presently joined by the Chorus (167). In the Sophoclean prologue also Orestes appears; then there is a monody for Electra (86â€”120); and she is joined by the Chorus (121). Such a coincidence, it is argued, cannot be accidental. And there is internal evidence that Euripides was the model. For, with him, the appearance of Orestes at that early moment is necessary; while, with Sophocles, there is no reason why Orestes should be seen until he is ready to enter the house. Again, the Chorus of Euripides have a motive for their visit; they invite Electra to a festival. But the Sophoclean Chorus come without any special cause. Nor has Sophocles the reason of Euripides for composing his Chorus of persons external to the palace; indeed, it is hard to see how such persons could have established such intimacy with Electra, who was almost a prisoner.

In reply to this argument I wish to point out, first, that the likeness between the two openings, in the particular points just noticed, is immeasurably less striking than the general contrast. The play of Sophocles begins with a dialogue between the old man and Orestes, after which they and Pylades leave the scene. Electra then comes forth and sings her monody. Euripides opens with a speech by the farmer, who next has a dialogue with Electra. They depart. Orestes enters with Pylades, to whom he makes a speech. Presently he sees a slave, as he thinksâ€”i.e. Electraâ€”approaching. He and Pylades draw aside; and Electra then sings her monody. Is it not manifest that, so far, the openings are fundamentally different? But, it will be said, the Parodos, at least, is, in each play, shared between Electra and the Chorus; is not this suspicious? Even here the contrast is stronger than the likeness. The Sophoclean Parodos is a long ode of 129 verses, containing a discussion of Electra's wrongs and hopes, and of the course which she ought to pursue. The Euripidean Parodos consists of only 35 verses. The maidens briefly invite Electra, and she declines.

It seems to me, then, that the openings of the two plays entirely fail to support the critic's major premiss, viz., that one of them must have been imitated from the other. But let us assume, for the sake of argument, that such imitation could be proved. Is it true that internal evidence points to Sophocles as the imitator? His Orestes, we are told, has no reason for appearing at the house before he is prepared to enter it. In defending a dramatist on such a point, it suffices, I suppose, to show that the action is natural and probable; we are not required to prove that it is necessary. Orestes and his companions have just arrived, and have hidden the urn somewhere near the house: the time is day-break. Is it strange that they should reconnoitre the ground on which they will soon have to act, or that the old man should point out the chief features of the scene? As to the poet's motive, that is evident. His invention of the double embassy from Phocis was a novelty, and he wished to give a clue to it at the outset, since the spectator, who is thus in the secret, will enjoy the play more. Again, it is said that Sophocles bewrays his model when he composes his Chorus of persons external to the house. A desire to vary from Aeschylus would account for this as easily as a desire to copy Euripides; but why should not the poet's motive have been independent of both? The free-born women of Mycenae are exponents of the public goodwill towards the rightful heir. But how, we are asked, had they become friends of Electra? Chrysothemis and Clytaemnestra tell us, it may be answered, that Electra frequently passed beyond the doors. Lastly, it is objected that the Chorus come to Electra without a definite reason. Is there not reason enough in their purpose of consoling and counselling her,â€”the purpose which she gratefully acknowledges?

Thus, even if the openings of the two plays could justly be regarded as showing a debt of either to the other, still there would be no presumption that Sophocles was the debtor.

Relation of Electra to Clytaemnestra.A further argument is, however, adduced in support of the view which we are discussing. Both Sophocles and Euripides bring Electra into controversy with Clytaemnestra. In the play of Euripides, the tenor of this controversy is such as to mitigate the odiousness of Clytaemnestra, and to emphasise the hardness of Electra. This was what Euripides meant to do. The aim of Sophocles was the opposite, to concentrate our sympathy upon Electra. But, says Prof. v. Wilamowitz, Sophocles has involuntarily given the advantage in dignity and self-command to Clytaemnestra; and this shows that he has (unskilfully) imitated Euripides. Is it true that the Clytaemnestra of Sophocles appears to more advantage than his Electra? Every reader must judge for himself; I should not have said so, nor, indeed, do I find it easy to understand how any one could receive that impression. But, even if this were granted, the inference of an imitation would still be unwarranted, since the controversies in the two plays respectively differ both in topics and in style.

Finally, let us consider the more general ground upon which Argument from general probability. it is argued that Sophocles was stimulated to write his Electra by the work of Euripides. The Euripidean Electra is certainly a play which Sophocles would have viewed with repugnance. He would have thought that both the divine and the human persons were degraded. The earlier scenes, with their homely realism, approximate, in fact, to the stamp of the Middle Comedy. The whole treatment is a negation of that ideal art to which Sophocles had devoted his life. It is perfectly conceivable that such a piece should have roused him to make a protest,â€”to show how the theme could once more be nobly treated, as Aeschylus long ago had treated it, and yet without raising the moral and religious problem of the Choephori. But is such a hypothesis more probable than the converse? Suppose that the Sophoclean Electra was the earlier of the two. Is it not equally conceivable that Euripides should have been stirred to protest against the calm condonation of matricide? Might he not have wished to show how the subject could be handled without ignoring, as Sophocles does, this aspect of the vengeance, and also without refraining from criticism on the solution propounded by Aeschylus? This, in my belief, is what Euripides actually did wish to do. But assume for a moment that the other theory is right, and that the Euripidean Electra was the earlier. Then, surely, when Euripides had just been renewing the impression left by Aeschylus,â€”that matricide, though enjoined by a god, brings a fearful stain,â€”Sophocles would have chosen a peculiarly unfortunate moment for inviting Athenians to admire the unruffled equanimity of his Orestes.

Conclusion.I cannot, then, see any valid reason for supposing that Euripides preceded Sophocles in treating this subject. On the other hand, the new line taken by Euripides is the more intelligible if he had before him the pieces of both the elder dramatistsEur. El. 883 f. (á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï‡ÏÎµá¿–Î¿Î½ á¼•ÎºÏ€Î»ÎµÎ¸ÏÎ¿Î½ Î´ÏÎ±Î¼á½¼Î½ | á¼€Î³á¿¶Î½â€™ á¼Ï‚ Î¿á¼´ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï‚) seems to glance at Soph. El. 680â€”763..

The Electra of Sophocles is one of his later plays.

20 Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ Î¿á½–Î½ Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ á¼Î¾Î¿Î´Î¿Î¹Ï€Î¿ÏÎµá¿–Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½³Î³Î·Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 20

There are, however, strong grounds of internal coincidence for believing that the Electra is among the later plays of Sophocles. It cannot, on any view, be placed more than a few years before the Euripidean Electra, of which the probable date is 413 B.C. The traits which warrant this conclusion are the Internal evidence.following. (1) The frequency of á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î»Î±Î²á½µ, i.e. the partition of an iambic trimeter between two speakers. The ordinary form of such partition is when each person speaks once, so that the trimeter falls into two parts (a, b). Taking the two latest plays, we find 22 such examples in the Philoctetes, and 52 in the Oedipus Coloneus. The Electra ranks between them, with 25. Next comes the Oedipus Tyrannus, with only 10. Further, verse 1502 of Electra is so divided between two persons that it falls into three parts (a, b, a). The other Sophoclean instances of this are confined to the Philoctetes (810, 814, 816) Ph. 753 is unique in being similarly divided so that it falls into four parts., and the Oedipus Coloneus (832).

(2) Anapaestic verses (1160â€”1162) are inserted in a series of iambic trimeters. The only parallel for this occurs in the Trachiniae (v. 1081, vv. 1085 f.), a piece which may be placed somewhere between 420 and 410 B.C. (Introd. to Trach., p. xxiii). It was an innovation due to the melodramatic tendency which marked the last two decades of the century. In the earlier practice, a series of iambic trimeters could be broken only by shorter iambic measures, or by mere interjections.

(3) The â€˜freeâ€™ or â€˜melicâ€™ anapaests in El. 86â€”120Vv. 88 f. are two successive paroemiacs. are of a type which can be strictly matched only in plays of a date later than circ. 420 B.C., such as the Troades, the Ion, and the Iphigeneia in Tauris.

(4) The actors have a notably large share in the lyric element of the play. (a) Thus the anapaests just mentioned are delivered by Electra as a Î¼Î¿Î½á¿³Î´á½·Î±. Such a monody can be paralleled only from the later plays of Euripides. It is characteristic of the new musicâ€”satirised by Aristophanes in the Frogsâ€”which came into vogue circ. 420 B.C. (b) Again, the Parodos of the Electra is in the form of a lyric dialogue (ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚) between the heroine and the Chorus. Here, too, it is only in the latest plays that we find parallels. A â€˜kommaticâ€™ parodos occurs also in the Oedipus Coloneus. That of the Philoctetes has something of the same general character, although there Neoptolemus replies to the Chorus only in anapaests. (c) Another illustration of the same tendency is the lyric duet between Electra and the coryphaeus in vv. 823â€”870, which may be compared with similar duets in the Philoctetes (e.g. 1170 ff.), and the Oedipus Coloneus (178 ff., 1677 ff.). (d) In the Î¼á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½á¿†Ï‚ between Electra and Orestes (1232â€”1287), the Chorus take no part. On the other hand, the songs given to the Chorus alone are of relatively small compass (472â€”515; 1058â€”1097; 1384â€”1397).

(5) The Parodos shows different classes of metre (the Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Î½ and the Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á½±ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î½) combined within the same strophe; and, at the close, the epode re-echoes them all. This Ï€Î¿Î»Ï…Î¼ÎµÏ„Ïá½·Î± is a further sign of a late periodSee Metrical Analysis, p. lxxiii. These lyric criteria for the date are searchingly examined by Prof. v. Wilamowitz in Hermes, vol. XVIII. pp. 242 ff..

When all these indications are considered, there seems to be Conclusio at least a very strong probability that the Electra was written not earlier than 420 B.C. There is only one point that might seem to favour an earlier date. The long syllables of the trimeter are here resolved more rarely than in any other of the seven extant playsThe statistics are given in G. Wolff's Elektra (3rd ed., revised by L. Bellermann), p. 123, n. 1. The ratio of the number of resolved feet to the whole number of trimeters in each play is stated as follows:â€” 1. Electra, 1 to 30 1/2. 2. Antigone, 1 to 26. 3. Trachiniae, 1 to 18 1/2. 4. Ajax, 1 to 18. 5. Oedipus Coloneus, 1 to 18. 6. Oedipus Tyrannus, 1 to 14 1/2. 7. Philoctetes, 1 to 9 1/2. The extraordinarily high proportion in the Philoctetes (409 B.C.) must be considered as indicative of the poet's latest period, and showing the influence of Euripides. But the danger of inference from a comparison of lower ratios is evident. The ratio in the Oedipus Coloneus is lower than in the earlier Tyrannus, and only the same as in the Ajax, which is the oldest play after the Antigone.. But, though a very great frequency of such resolution (as in the Philoctetes) has a clear significance, a negative application of the test would be, as the statistics show, most unsafe; and, in this instance, all the other internal evidence is on the opposite side. Those, then, who hold (as I do) that the play was produced before the Electra of Euripides (413 B.C.), will conclude that the years 420 and 414 B.C. mark the limits of the period to which it may be referred.

Ancient repute of the play. Translation by Atilius.

Î¾Ï…Î½á½±Ï€Ï„ÎµÏ„Î¿Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½Â· á½¡Ï‚ á¼Î½Ï„Î±á¿¦Î¸â€™ á¼Î¼á½³Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 21

The Electra of Sophocles was a favourite with Greek and Roman readers, as traces in literature indicateCephisodorus (circ. 340 B.C.), the pupil of Isocrates, alludes to verse 61 of the Electra (Athen. p. 122 C). Machon of Corinth (circ. 270 B.C.), who became eminent at Alexandria as a comic poet, tells a story of which the point turns on the first two verses of the play (Athen. p. 579 B). Dioscorides (circ. 230 B.C.), in a well-known epigram (Anthol. Pal. 7. 37), imagines the tomb of Sophocles surmounted by the figure of an actor, holding in his hand a tragic mask of the type called á¼¡ ÎºÎ¿á½»ÏÎ¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ (Pollux IV. Â§ 139), i.e., with the hair clipped in sign of mourning. Of this mask, the actor says:â€” Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ á¼ˆÎ½Ï„Î¹Î³á½¹Î½Î·Î½ Îµá¼°Ï€Îµá¿–Î½ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î½, Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ á¼Î¼á½±ÏÏ„Î¿Î¹Ï‚, Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼¨Î»á½³ÎºÏ„ÏÎ±Î½Â· á¼€Î¼Ï†á½¹Ï„ÎµÏÎ±Î¹ Î³á½°Ï á¼„ÎºÏÎ¿Î½. Cicero's judgment (De Fin. 1. 2) is cited below. The Electra of Propertius (3. 6. 5 f.) is the Sophoclean:â€”Electra, salvum cum aspexit Oresten, | cuius falsa tenens fleverat ossa soror ( Soph. El. 1126 ff.).. It was translated into Latin by a poet named Atilius, who lived probably in the early part of the second century B.C.Teuffel, Hist. Rom. Lit. vol. 1. Â§ 96, identifies this Atilius with the writer of palliatae in the time of Caecilius. This version, though it is unfavourably judged by Cicero De Fin. 1. 2 A quibus (viz., the depreciators of Latin literature) tantum dissentio ut, cum Sophocles vel optime scripserit Electram, tamen male conversam Atilii mihi legendam putem. In the same passage Atilius is described (by a critic whom Cicero quotes) as a â€˜ferreus scriptor,â€™ and in Epp. ad Att. 14. 20, Â§ 3, as â€˜poeta durissimus.â€™ Cicero's brother Quintus wrote an Electraâ€”one of four tragedies which he finished in sixteen days (Ad Qu. Fr. 3. 5, Â§ 7)., seems to have acquired some popularity, since, according to Suetonius, it was one of two pieces from which the verses sung at the funeral of Julius Caesar were adapted,â€”the other being the Armorum Iudicium of Pacuvius Iul. Caes. 84..

á¼µÎ½â€™ Î¿á½Îºá½³Ï„â€™ á½€ÎºÎ½Îµá¿–Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¹Ï‚, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼”ÏÎ³Ï‰Î½ á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½µ. ğŸ—©
Line 22

Two modern plays on the subject,â€”the Oreste of The Oreste of Voltaire. Voltaire and the Oreste of Alfieri,â€”so directly invite a comparison with the Greek dramatists, and especially with Sophocles, that they claim a brief notice here. Each is, in its own way, the work of one who has endeavoured to seize the spirit of antiquity; who appreciates the charms of the Greek treatment; and who wishes to preserve the beauty of Greek outline, while telling the story in a new manner, such as he deems more effective for the modern theatre. Each play thus becomes a suggestive criticism on the antique.

Voltaire was not the first French dramatist who had handled this theme. CrÃ©billon, whose Ã‰lectre appeared in 1708, had followed the precedent set in the Å’dipe of Corneille (1657), by interweaving love-affairs with the tragic action: the son of Aegisthus has won the heart of Electra, and his daughter is beloved by Orestes. Longepierre, whose Ã‰lectre was acted in 1719, failed for a different reason; he preserved the classical simplicity, but lacked knowledge of the stage and charm of style. Voltaire's Oreste was produced in 1750. In the letter of dedication prefixed to it, he says that his aim is to restore a purer taste; and he thus describes the relation of his work to the Sophoclean. â€˜I have not copied the Electra of Sophocles,â€” far from it; but I have reproduced, as well as I could, its spirit and its substanceâ€˜Je n'ai point copiÃ© l'Ã‰lectre de Sophocle, il s'en faut beaucoup; j'en ai pris, autant que j'ai pu, tout l'esprit et toute la substance.â€™ Ã‰pÃ®tre Ã  la Duchesse du Maine, in Beuchot's Å’uvres de Voltaire, vol. VI. p. 157..â€™ This is true; it is only in general outline that his plot resembles the other; the details are his own. The scene is laid near the tomb of Agamemnon, on the shore of the Argolic Gulf. Thither, from Argos, come Aegisthus and Clytaemnestra, to hold a festivalA touch borrowed from Soph. El. 278 ff.; bringing with them Electra, their slave, with fetters on her wrists. On the same day, Orestes and Pylades are driven ashore at a neighbouring spot, and fall in with PammÃ¨neAs PammÃ¨ne answers to the Sophoclean Paedagogus, the Sophoclean Chrysothemis has a counterpart in Iphise, who has been allowed to dwell apart, in an old palace near the tomb., a faithful old retainer of the house, who becomes their accomplice. The disguised Orestes, with Pylades, presents himself to Aegisthus, bearing a funeral urn. It contains, he says, the ashes of Orestes, whom he has slain at Epidaurus. There are, in fact, human ashes in the urn; but they are those of PlistÃ¨ne, the son of Aegisthus, whom his father had sent to kill Orestes. Presently Aegisthus learns by a message that his son is dead. He promptly arrests the two young strangers, and PammÃ¨ne also. Meanwhile Orestes has met Electra at the tomb, and, overcome by affection and pity, has made himself known to her; though the oracle of Delphi had strictly forbidden him to do so. Electra now appeals to Clytaemnestraâ€”tells her the secretâ€”and persuades her to intercede with Aegisthus, but without divulging her son's identity. Clytaemnestra complies. Aegisthusâ€”now certain that Orestes is in his handsâ€”spurns her prayer, and sends the two youths to instant death. They are saved by a popular rising at Argos. The people acclaim Orestes as their king. He then takes vengeance. Electra hears Clytaemnestra's cry of supplication (behind the scenes), and, believing that her mother is pleading for Aegisthus, cries to her brother, â€˜Strike!â€™Act V, Sc. 8. The trait is borrowed from Soph. El. 1415, ÎšÎ›. á½¤Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï€á½³Ï€Î»Î·Î³Î¼Î±Î¹. Î—Î›. Ï€Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¿Î½, Îµá¼° ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¿†Î½: but the new setting given to it by the French dramatist is admirably ingenious. The next moment Clytaemnestra is heard crying, â€˜My son, I die by thy hand!â€™ Electra is overwhelmed with horror; and the play ends with the anguish of Orestes, who prepares to go forth into exile.

The feature which Voltaire himself regarded as most distinctive of his work is the character of Clytaemnestra. He has caught up the hint given by Sophocles (vv. 766 ff.), and carried further by Euripides, that the murderess of Agamemnon may remain capable of tenderness for Orestes and Electra. The Clytaemnestra of Voltaire can be touched by the entreaties of her children, though she replies to their taunts with anger and scornÃ‰pÃ®tre (prefixed to the Oreste), p. 157. â€˜Rien n'est en effet plus dans la nature qu'une femme criminelle envers son Ã©poux, et qui se laisse attendrir par ses enfants, qui reÃ§oit la pitiÃ© dans son cÅ“ur altier et farouche, qui s'irrite, qui reprend la duretÃ© de son caractÃ¨re quand on lui fait des reproches trop violents, et qui s'apaise ensuite par les soumissions et par les larmes.â€™. â€˜The germ of this personage,â€™ he says, â€˜was in Sophocles and Euripides, and I have developed it.â€™ In doing so, he has gone a little too far; the â€˜cri du sangâ€™ is somewhat too obtrusive and theatrical. Greek Tragedy, with its severe sanity, would have felt that there was extravagance in making Clytaemnestra intercede with Aegisthus for the life of one who could return only as an avenger. Nevertheless, the French dramatist has derived many touches of real beauty and pathos from this motiveAs in the scene between Clytaemnestra, Electra, and Iphise (the Chrysothemis of the play), Act 1, Sc. 3; and in the scenes where Clytaemnestra pleads with Aegisthus for Orestes (Act 1, Sc. 5; Act V, Sc. 3).. His other chief innovation consists in rendering the course of the stratagem less smooth. Orestes and Pylades are placed in deadly peril. Our hopes and fears alternate almost to the end. The demand for this kind of interest is modern. An old Greek audience, familiar beforehand with the main lines of the story, could feel no anxiety for the safety of the hero. Voltaire's treatment of the urn-scene is noteworthy. He saw that here it was impossible to reproduce the Sophoclean pathos; that was only for people who had this custom in respect to the relics of the dead,â€”a custom surrounded with sacred and tender associations. Voltaire substituted an interest of a different kind, â€”the thrill felt by the spectators who know that the urn presented to Aegisthus contains the ashes of his sonâ€˜Il a fallu supplÃ©er au pathÃ©tique qu'ils [i.e. les anciens] y trouvaient par la terreur que doit inspirer la vue des cendres de PlistÃ¨ne, premiÃ¨re victime de la vengeance d'Oreste.â€™ This remark occurs in an essay published in the same year as Voltaire's play (1750),â€”Dissertation sur les principales TragÃ©dies anciennes et modernes, qui ont paru sur le sujet d'Ã‰lectre, et en particulier sur celle de Sophocle. It appeared under the name of M. Dumolard, a critic of the day; but it clearly reveals the mind, if not the pen, of Voltaire, among whose works it has long been included: see Beuchot, Å’uvres de Voltaire, vol. VI. p. 255. The words quoted above are on p. 279.. The device is ingenious, but reduces the incident to a lower level; it is no longer a dramatic beauty, but rather a stroke of theatrical effect. A more serious departure from the ancient model is involved in his attempt to vindicate the gods. He refuses to conceive that they could have commanded an innocent man to slay his mother, however guilty she might be. In his version, they ultimately doom Orestes to do so; but only as a punishment. And for what? For having failed, through love and pity, to persevere in obedience to their arbitrary command against revealing him self to his sisterDissertation, etc. p. 281: â€˜Oreste est certainement plus Ã  plaindre dans l'auteur franÃ§ais que dans l'athÃ©nien, et la divinitÃ© y est plus mÃ©nagÃ©e.â€™ The Orestes of Voltaire is indeed to be pitied; but precisely because the divine caprice is so frightful.. This surely does not exhibit their justice in a more favourable light. So perilous is it to tamper with Greek Tragedy on this side,â€”as Euripides, indeed, was the first to show. The inscrutable destiny interwoven with the legend is a thread which cannot be removed without marring the whole texture.

The Oreste of Alfieri.


á½ˆÎ¡á¿‰Î£Î¤Î—Î£
á½¦ Ï†á½·Î»Ï„Î±Ï„â€™ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ€á½¹Î»Ï‰Î½, á½¥Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î¹ ÏƒÎ±Ï†á¿† ğŸ—©
Line 23

A lesson of a different kind is taught by the Oreste of AlfieriIt was published in 1783, when the poet was thirty-four years of age.. More rigorous than the ancients themselves in limiting the number of the characters, he employs only five persons,â€” Aegisthus, Orestes, Pylades, Clytaemnestra, and Electra. Sophocles is the classical poet who has chiefly influenced him in detail; but he owes still more to Voltaire. His Clytaemnestra is a woman broken down by misery and remorse; despised by Aegisthus; upbraided by Electra; vacillating between hysterical tenderness for her children and returns of the old passion for her paramour. Orestes arrives, with Pylades, and is recognised by Electra merely through the emotions which he manifests at the tomb of Agamemnon. The youths then announce, first to Clytaemnestra and afterwards to Aegisthus, the news that Orestes has been killed in a Cretan chariot-race. Aegisthus detects the fiction owing to the folly of Orestes, who, throughout the play, is incapable of self-control; he is perpetually reproved, or helped out of difficulties, by the more prudent Pylades. Aegisthus orders the young men to be executed, and dooms Electra to the same fate. They are saved, as with Voltaire, by an insurrection of the Argives. Orestes then takes the righteous vengeance. He slays Aegisthus, and at the same moment, in his blind fury, unconsciously deals a death-wound to Clytaemnestra, who is endeavouring to protect the tyrant. The play closes with his incipient madness, when he learns from Electra and Pylades that he has shed a mother's blood.

Alfieri has a genuine, though limited, sympathy with the classical spirit, and, unlike most of his modern predecessors in the treatment of such themes, avoids everything that is positively incongruous with that spirit. It is the more instructive to observe the reason why he fails, in this Oreste, to be truly classical. An Attic tragedy, though severely simple in outline, owes much of its artistic charm to those minor incidents which diversify the plot, and to those secondary persons who serve as foils or contrasts to the chief actors. The part of the Nurse in the Choephori is a small one, and yet how much the play would lose if it were omitted! In the Electra of Sophocles, the Old Man is not merely a link in a chain of agency, but a source of dramatic interest: and the portraiture of the heroine herself is the more vivid because Chrysothemis is placed at her side. It is this variety and relief, this skilful use of undertones, that we miss in the work of the Italian dramatist. He has cut out everything that is not indispensable. Without deviation or pause, the action pursues its direct, but somewhat monotonous courseCharles Lloyd, in the preface to his English translation of Alfieri's Tragedies (vol. I. p. xxvii, Lond. 1815), quotes some remarks of Madame de Stael (in Corinne): â€”â€˜Alfieri, par un hasard singulier, Ã©tait, pour ainsi dire, transplantÃ© de l'antiquitÃ© dans les temps modernes; il Ã©tait nÃ© pour agir, et il n'a pu qu'Ã©crire... Il a voulu donner Ã  ses tragÃ©dies le caractÃ¨re le plus austÃ¨re. Il en a retranchÃ© les confidens, les coups de thÃ©Ã¢tre, tout, hors l'intÃ©rÃªt du dialogue.â€™ â€˜Austerityâ€™ is indeed the word which best describes the general stamp of his tragedies. He represents a reaction from the extravagance of Italian drama in the seventeenth century; but his endeavour after classical form is that of a mind which had more force and passion than sensibility or imagination.. There are occasional beautiesConspicuous among these is the scene at the tomb, where Electra divines the identity of Orestes by overhearing his outburst of grief and vows of vengeance, while Pylades (fearing a recognition) pretends to her that his friend is of unsound mind (Act II, Sc. 2). A few verses, which immediately precede the discovery, will serve to give some idea of the style:â€” ELETTRA. Gli sguardi Fissi ei tien sulla tomba, immoti, ardenti; Ãˆ terribile in atto...â€”O tu, chi sei, Che generoso ardisci?... ORESTE. A me la cura Lasciane, a me. PILADE. GiÃ  piÃ¹ non t' ode. O donna, Scusa i trasporti insani: ai detti suoi Non badar punto: Ã¨ fuor di se.â€”Scoprirti Vuoi dunque a forza? ORESTE. ImmergerÃ² il mio brando Nel traditor tante fiate e tante, Quante versasti dalla orribil piaga Stille di sangue. ELETTRA. Ei non vaneggia. Un padre... ORESTE. SÃ¬, mi fu tolto un padre. Oh rabbia! E inulto Rimane ancora? ELETTRA. E chi sarai tu dunque, Se Oreste non sei tu? PILADE. Che ascolto? ORESTE. Oreste! Chi, chi mi appella? PILADE. Or sei perduto. ELETTRA. Elettra Ti appella; Elettra io son, che al sen ti stringo Fra le mie braccia., but the general effect is not that of a Greek drama; it is rather that of an abridgement from such a work. Thus both Voltaire and Alfieriâ€”the two moderns who, in treating the story of Electra, have been most closely studious of the classical modelsâ€”have, in their different ways, something to teach us with regard to those qualities which distinguish the Greek masterpiecesM. Patin (Ã‰tudes sur les Tragiques grecs, vol. II. pp. 382 ff.) notices, among other plays on this subject, two which present certain points of interest. One is the Clytemnestre of SoumetAlex. , produced in 1822, when the part of Orestes was acted by Talma. The influence of the Greek dramatists is mingled with that of Alfieri. Unlike his modern predecessors, the author makes use of Clytaemnestra's dream, to which he gives a new and striking form. From the Orestie of Dumas Alex. (produced in 1856) is cited a beautiful lament of Electra (Act II, Sc. 6), an echo of several passages in Sophocles..

Traces in art of the Aeschylean and Sophoclean plays.

ÏƒÎ·Î¼Îµá¿–Î± Ï†Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î»á½¸Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á¾¶Ï‚ Î³ÎµÎ³á½½Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 24

We have already seen how the lyric Oresteia of Stesichorus is related to certain works of Greek art. It may be interesting, in conclusion, to observe how far the dramatic versions of the story can be traced in that province. As might have been expected, the Aeschylean trilogy has been the most influential. Thus the Choephori has helped to inspire a vase-paintingThe vase is from Lower Italy, and is now at Naples: Rochette, Mon. inÃ©dit. pl. 34. It is reproduced in Baumeister's DenkmÃ¤ler, p. 1111, with Overbeck's interpretation of it. in which Electra, Orestes and Pylades, with some other figures, are seen at the grave of Agamemnon,â€”the god Hermes (whom Orestes invokes at the beginning of that play) being also present. The passage of the Eumenides which alludes to the purification of Orestes by the blood of swine (ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±ÏÎ¼Î¿á½¶ Ï‡Î¿Î¹ÏÎ¿ÎºÏ„á½¹Î½Î¿Î¹, v. 283) is illustrated by another vaseFrom Apulia, published in Mon. Inst. IV. 48: Baumeister, Denkm. p. 1117.; Apollo, at Delphi, is holding a slain sucking-pig over the head of Orestes, while the ghost of Clytaemnestra seeks to arouse the slumbering Furies. In a third vase-pictureMillin, Peintures de Vases, II. 68: Baumeister, Denkm. p. 1118., also indebted to the Eumenides (187â€”223), we see the Furies now awake, and about to resume their chase of Orestes; Apollo, at his side, sternly reproves them; while the benign figure of Athena, to whom Orestes looks up, typifies his approaching acquittal at Athens. Lastly, the crisis in the trial on the hill of Ares, when the goddess places her pebble in the urn, is depicted on a vaseFound at Kertsch: Baumeister, Denkm. p. 1119, where Stephani's explanation of it is given. of the later Roman age. The Electra of Sophocles has suggested the subject represented on an Apulian vaseReproduced by Prof. Michaelis A. at the head of the Preface to his revision of Otto Jahn's Sophoclis Electra (3rd ed., p. iii, Bonn, 1892). He refers (p. vii) to the publications and interpretations of the vase by Laborde (Vases Lamberg I, pl. 8), J. de Witte and C. Lenormant (Ã‰lite cÃ©ramogr. II. pl. 79), and Overbeck (Bildwerke pl. 29, 61).; Orestes, wearing a chlamys, and carrying a spear in his left hand, shows a funeral urn to Electra; Pylades, also with chlamys and spear, follows him. The moment is that at which the two youths, disguised as Phocian messengers from Strophius, arrive before the gates of the palace, and inform Electra of their errand (1113 f.):â€”

Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÏƒÎ¼Î¹ÎºÏá½° Î»Îµá½·ÏˆÎ±Î½â€™ á¼Î½ Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡Îµá¿– Ï„Îµá½»Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚, á½¡Ï‚ á½Ïá¾·Ï‚, ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½.

A marble groupReproduced in Baumeister's Denkm. p. 1192; and by Michaelis in Jahn's Electra, p. 31., now in the Museum at Naples, represents a youth standing at the right side of a maiden whose outstretched right arm encircles his neck, the hand resting on his right shoulder. This work, remarkable for a grave and chastened beauty, is suggestive of an elder sister with her brother; and, according to a probable interpretationThis view is accepted by Prof. Michaelis (op. cit. p. vii). According to others, the persons are Merope and her son Cresphontes (from the Cresphontes of Euripides); or Deianeira exhorting her son Hyllus to go in search of Heracles ( Soph. Tr. 82 ff.); or Penelope and Telemachus. The group is the work of Stephanus, a pupil of MenelaÃ¼s, himself the pupil of Pasiteles, a sculptor and versatile artist of Lower Italy, who lived in the earlier half of the first century B.C. See Dr C. Waldstein's article on Pasiteles in Baumeister's DenkmÃ¤ler, p. 1190., the persons are Electra and Orestes. We are reminded of the sequel to the recognition in the play of Sophocles, where the sister says, á¼”Ï‡Ï‰ Î´Îµ Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½·Î½; and Orestes answers, á½¡Ï‚ Ï„á½° Î»Î¿á½·Ï€â€™ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼€Îµá½· (v. 1226); though the moment imagined by the sculptor is one when the first transport of joy has subsided into a calmer happiness. It remains to notice a slight but significant testimony to Sophoclean influence on the treatment of this subject in the art of the Imperial age. Lucian describes a picture in which Orestes and Pylades are slaying Aegisthus, while Clytaemnestra, already slain, is seen on a couchLucian Î ÎµÏá½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¿á¼´ÎºÎ¿Ï…, Â§ 23.. He commends the skill which fixes attention on the doom of a wicked man, but leaves in the background the vengeance taken on a mother by a son Î¹Î².ÏƒÎµÎ¼Î½á½¸Î½ Î´á½³ Ï„Î¹ á½ Î³ÏÎ±Ï†Îµá½ºÏ‚ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ½á½¹Î·ÏƒÎµÎ½, Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼€ÏƒÎµÎ²á½²Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá½µÏƒÎµÏ‰Ï‚ Î´Îµá½·Î¾Î±Ï‚ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½¡Ï‚ á¼¤Î´Î· Ï€ÎµÏ€ÏÎ±Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Î´ÏÎ±Î¼á½½Î½, á¼Î¼Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Î½Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Î´á½² Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î½ÎµÎ±Î½á½·ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼ÏÎ³Î±Ïƒá½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á¿· Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‡Î¿á¿¦ Ï†á½¹Î½á¿³.. Now, among the extant literary sources for the story, the Electra of Sophocles is the only one in which the death of Clytaemnestra precedes that of AegisthusWith regard to the authority followed by the painter, Lucian remarks, Ï„á½¸ á¼€ÏÏ‡á½³Ï„Ï…Ï€Î¿Î½ á½ Î³ÏÎ±Ï†Îµá½ºÏ‚ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ Î•á½ÏÎ¹Ï€á½·Î´Î¿Ï… á¼¢ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á½³Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿– Î¼Î¿Î¹ Î»Î±Î²Îµá¿–Î½, forgetting that no situation even distantly similar occurs in the play of the younger dramatist. Indeed, so far as I can discover, the Euripidean Electra is nowhere traceable in ancient art, to which it offered no specially suitable material. It will be observed that the picture described above does not agree in detail with the closing scene in the play of Sophocles; it is the order of the retributive acts, and the prominence given to them respectively, which unmistakably shows his influence.; and the effect for which Lucian gives credit to the painter is the same which is obtained, in a subtler form, by the dramatic perspective of the poet.

á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½Î¿á¿–Ï‚, in dangers: Thuc. 1. 70á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Îµá½á½³Î»Ï€Î¹Î´ÎµÏ‚; ib. 84 Ï„á¿¶Î½...á¼Î¾Î¿Ï„ÏÏ…Î½á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼¡Î¼á¾¶Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„á½° Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½±,

Line 42

Î³á½µÏá¾³ refers to the change in his appearance; Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Î¼Î±ÎºÏá¿·, to the lapse of seven years (v. 14), which may have caused him to be forgotten.

Î¿á½Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€Î¿Ï€Ï„Îµá½»ÏƒÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ follows Î¿á½ Î¼á½´ Î³Î½á¿¶ÏƒÎ¹, as in O. C. 450 ff. Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼¥Î¾ÎµÎ¹ follows Î¿á½ Î¼á½´ Î»á½±Ï‡Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹. The latter example is so far less harsh that the verbs have different subjects; but it shows how these two forms of future statements could be strictly co-ordinated. No correction is probable. (á½‘Ï€Î¿Ï€Ï„Îµá½»ÏƒÏ‰ÏƒÎ¹Î½ would require, of course, Î¼Î·Î´).)

á½§Î´â€™ á¼ Î½Î¸Î¹ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½, with grey hair: O. T. 742Î»ÎµÏ…ÎºÎ±Î½Î¸á½²Ï‚ Îºá½±ÏÎ±: Erinna fr. 2 Ï€Î±Ï…ÏÎ¿Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹ Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Î±á½·, Ï„Î±á½¶ Î³á½µÏÎ±Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Î½Î¸ÎµÎ± Î¸Î½Î±Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚. Î³Î½á¿¶Ïƒâ€™, Î¿á½Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€Î¿Ï€Ï„Îµá½»ÏƒÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½§Î´â€™ á¼ Î½Î¸Î¹ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½.
Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ Î´á½² Ï‡Ïá¿¶ Ï„Î¿Î¹á¿·Î´â€™, á½…Ï„Î¹ Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Îµá¼¶
45 Î¦Ï‰Îºá½³Ï‰Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¦Î±Î½Î¿Ï„á½³Ï‰Ï‚ á¼¥ÎºÏ‰Î½Â· á½ƒ Î³á½°Ï ğŸ—©
Line 45

Î¦Ï‰ÎºÎµá½»Ï‚ should not be changed to Î¦Ï‰Îºá½³Ï‰Ï‚: it was desirable that the messenger himself should seem an alien. Similarly Orestes and Pylades come as Î¦Ï‰Îºá¿†Ï‚ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚ (1107).

á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¦Î±Î½Î¿Ï„á½³Ï‰Ï‚. á¼€Î½á½µÏ, thus prefixed to a proper name, serves either: (a) to introduce a person not previously men tioned,â€”being more respectful than Ï„Î¹Ï‚, as Il. 11. 92á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± Î’Î¹á½µÎ½Î¿ÏÎ±, Her. 8. 82á¼€Î½á½´Ï Î Î±Î½Î±á½·Ï„Î¹Î¿Ï‚: or (b) adds something of solemnity or pathos to the mention of a familiar name, as Soph. O. C. 109á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎŸá¼°Î´á½·Ï€Î¿Ï…, Soph. Ai. 817á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼ÎºÏ„Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚.

Phanoteus was the eponymous hero of the town Phanoteus ( Thuc. 4. 89), or Panopeus ( Il. 2. 520 etc., Paus. , Strabo), in Phocis, close to the Boeotian frontier, â€”about three miles west of Chaeroneia, and as many east of Daulis. He was the brother of Crisus, from whom the town of Crisa in Phocis (about two miles w. s. w. of Delphi) took its name. Between these brothers, said the legend, there was a deadly feud; before birth they had struggled in the womb (Tzetzes, Lycophr. 939: cp. Preller, Griechische Mythologie, 2. p. 54 n. 5). Now Crisus was the father of Strophius, that king of Crisa who was the ally of Agamemnon, and with whom the young Orestes found a home. Hence Phanoteus, the foe of Crisus, is represented as the friend of Aegisthus and Clytaemnestra. He is the first to send them the glad tidings that Orestes is dead. On the other hand it is Strophius who is described as paying the last honours to the corpse, and sending the ashes to Mycenae (1111).

á½ Î³á½°Ï: other instances of the art., as demonstr. pron., immediately followed by Î³á½±Ï (and not by Î¼á½³Î½ or Î´á½³) are, O. T. 1082ï¼ˆÏ„á¿†Ï‚), O. T. 1102ï¼ˆÏ„á¿·), Ph. 154ï¼ˆÏ„á½¹). The art. á½, á¼¡, when it stands as demonstr. pron., is sometimes written á½…, á¼¥: a practice which is recognised by Eustathius (p. 23. 3, on Il. 1. 9), but which seems to rest on no good ground.

Î¼á½³Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î´Î¿ÏÏ…Î¾á½³Î½Ï‰Î½. ğŸ—©

Î¼á½³Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚, as in Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½³Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ ( Ph. 586, Ai. 1331) simply, â€˜greatestâ€™ friend; not, â€˜most powerful.â€™

Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹, without á½¤Î½: cp. 313, 1457: Ai. 9 á¼”Î½Î´Î¿Î½... Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹ . Ast collects some ten examples from Plato; a few are subject to the doubt whether á½„Î½ or á½¤Î½ has not dropped out after a like termination; but that does not apply to (e.g.) Hipp. Ma. 300 A á¼¡ Î´á¼° á¼€ÎºÎ¿á¿†Ï‚ á¼¡Î´Î¿Î½á½´...Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹ ÎºÎ±Î»á½µ , or Tim. 61 D Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹...Î´Ï…Î½Î±Ï„á½° á¼±ÎºÎ±Î½á¿¶Ï‚ Î»ÎµÏ‡Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ .

Î´Î¿ÏÏ…Î¾á½³Î½Ï‰Î½: a word applied by the tragedians to a prince or chief who is in armed alliance with the head of another state: see on O. C. 632.

á¼„Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î»Îµ Î´â€™ á½…ÏÎºÎ¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ á½Î¸Î¿á½»Î½ÎµÎºÎ± ğŸ—©
Line 47

á½…ÏÎºÎ¿Î½, Reiske's correction of á½…ÏÎºá¿³, seems right. With á½…ÏÎºá¿³, the choice is between two explanations. (1) á¼„Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î»Îµ á½…ÏÎºá¿³, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ (á½…ÏÎºÎ¿Î½). This is exceedingly awkward, and is not really similar to Ar. Av. 1004á½€ÏÎ¸á¿· Î¼ÎµÏ„Ïá½µÏƒÏ‰ ÎºÎ±Î½á½¹Î½Î¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚ (ÎºÎ±Î½á½¹Î½Î±): for Î¼ÎµÏ„Ïá½µÏƒÏ‰ is most naturally followed by the dative of the instrument; while á¼€Î³Î³á½³Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹Î½ á½…ÏÎºá¿³ would be a strange phrase. (2) á¼„Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î»Îµ á½…ÏÎºá¿³ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ (Ï„á½° á¼€Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î»á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î±): explained as an â€˜inversionâ€™ of Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ á½…ÏÎºÎ¿Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼€Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚. But it is hard to see how â€˜adding the report to an oathâ€™ could stand for â€˜adding an oath to the report.â€™

On the other hand, the phrase Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î¸á½³Î½Î±Î¹ á½…ÏÎºÎ¿Î½ has the authority of Sophocles himself: fr. 431 á½…ÏÎºÎ¿Ï… Î´á½² Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹Î¼ÎµÎ»ÎµÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ± | ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½´ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÏƒÏ„Î·. Cp. too Tr. 255á½…ÏÎºÎ¿Î½ Î±á½‘Ï„á¿· Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ²Î±Î»á½½Î½.

The false oath would be regarded as excused by the Î´á½¹Î»Î¿Î¹ which Apollo had prescribed (v. 37); but in fact the Paedagogus takes no such oath.

Ï„á½³Î¸Î½Î·Îºâ€™ á½ˆÏá½³ÏƒÏ„Î·Ï‚ á¼Î¾ á¼€Î½Î±Î³ÎºÎ±á½·Î±Ï‚ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î·Ï‚, ğŸ—©
Line 48

á¼€Î½Î±Î³ÎºÎ±á½·Î±Ï‚ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î·Ï‚, an accident ordained by á¼€Î½Î±Î³ÎºÎ·, fate ( O. C. 605). The phrase recurs, with a somewhat different context, in Ai. 485, Ai. 803.

á¼„Î¸Î»Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ (from á¼†Î¸Î»Î¿Ï‚) Î Ï…Î¸Î¹ÎºÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½. Here and at v. 682 the schol. notes the anachronism,â€”to which Attic Tragedy was wholly indifferent. From very early times there was an á¼€Î³á½½Î½ at Delphi, but for music and poetry only. Athletic contests were first added when, on the conquest of Crisa by the Delphic Amphictyony, the festival was revived with a new splendour. The year Ol. 48. 3, 586 B.C. was that from which the Pythiads were dated ( Paus. 10. 7. 3). Cp. Curtius, Hist. Gr. 1. p. 266.

Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‡Î·Î»á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ implies â€˜rapid,â€™ â€˜whirlingâ€™: cp. I. T. 82 Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‡Î·Î»á½±Ï„Î¿Ï… | Î¼Î±Î½á½·Î±Ï‚.

á¼‘ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Ï‰: be so â€˜constitutedâ€™: i.e., the whole story is to rest upon this basis. Cp. Plat. Theaet. 171 D Ï„Î±á½»Ï„á¿ƒ á¼‚Î½ Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± á¼µÏƒÏ„Î±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ .

Î´Î¿Îºá¿¶ Î¼á½³Î½: cp. 547: O. C. 995 n.â€” Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Îºá½³ÏÎ´ÎµÎ¹ (á½„Î½), when fraught with gain: cp. 899 á½¡Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼Î½ Î³Î±Î»á½µÎ½á¿ƒ (sc. á½„Î½Ï„Î±) Ï€á½±Î½Ï„â€™ á¼Î´ÎµÏÎºá½¹Î¼Î·Î½ Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Î½. For Ïƒá½»Î½, cp. 430 Ïƒá½ºÎ½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿·.

ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½, â€˜ill-omenedâ€™; O. C. 1433, Ant. 1001.

á¼¤Î´Î· Î³á½°Ï Îµá¼¶Î´Î¿Î½ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½±ÎºÎ¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ ÏƒÎ¿Ï†Î¿á½ºÏ‚ ğŸ—©
Line 62

Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½±ÎºÎ¹Ï‚. There were many such popular stories. Pythagoras was said to have hidden himself in a subterranean chamber, causing his death to be reported; and when he reappeared, he was supposed to have been born anew (schol.). Herodotus tells a similar story of the Thracian Salmoxis, a slave and disciple of Pythagoras, who thus converted the Thracians to a doctrine of immortality (4. 95). So, too, the poet Aristeas of Proconnesus disappeared for seven years,â€”as a sort of preliminary advertisement, it would seem, to his poem the Arimaspeia ( Her. 4. 14). It is vain to ask what particular story or stories Sophocles was thinking of; very possibly he knew those in Herodotus (cp. Soph. O. C. 337 n.); but it was enough for him that his hearers would recognise the allusion to stories of that type. Hartung thinks that the reference is to Odysseus; but, as Odysseus did not contrive the rumour of his own death, the case is not in point.

Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ Î¼á½±Ï„Î·Î½ Î¸Î½á¿„ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚: for Î¼á½±Ï„Î·Î½ as =â€˜falsely,â€™ cp. 1298, Ph. 345.

á¼ÎºÏ„ÎµÏ„á½·Î¼Î·Î½Ï„Î±Î¹. The emphatic perf. might denote either (1) permanence,â€” â€˜they are in greater honour thenceforthâ€™; or (2) the instantaneous result,â€”â€˜forthwith.â€™ Perhaps the usage of the perf. pass. of Ï„Î¹Î¼á½±Ï‰ rather favours (1). Cp. O. C. 1304Ï„ÎµÏ„á½·Î¼Î·Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ Î´Î¿Ïá½· (with Thuc. 2. 45, cited there): Hom. Od. 7. 69(of ArÃªtÃ¨) Ï„ÎµÏ„á½·Î¼Î·Ï„Î±Î¹.â€” The finite verb, instead of á¼ÎºÏ„ÎµÏ„Î¹Î¼Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚, by a frequent idiom; cp. 192 (á¼€Î¼Ï†á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¼Î±Î¹): O. C. 351 n.â€”á¼ÎºÏ„Î¹Î¼á½±Ï‰ is rare in classical Greek. Arist. Oec. 2. 33(p. 1352 b 5) has á¼ÎºÏ„ÎµÏ„Î¹Î¼Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î± as=â€˜things on which a high price is set,â€™ opp. to Îµá½”Ï‰Î½Î±, â€˜cheap.â€™

Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ Î¼á½±Ï„Î·Î½ Î¸Î½á¿„ÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚Â· Îµá¼¶Î¸â€™, á½…Ï„Î±Î½ Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚

á½¡Ï‚, â€˜as,â€™ seems better here than á½£Ï‚, â€˜thus.â€™ It gives a smoother transition; and it is also more in accord with usage. á¼„Ï€Î¿, not merely â€˜afterâ€™ it, but as a result of it; cp. Ant. 695, Ph. 408.

Î´ÎµÎ´Î¿ÏÎºá½¹Ï„),=Î²Î»á½³Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„Î±, living: Aesch. Eum. 322á¼€Î»Î±Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´ÎµÎ´Î¿ÏÎºá½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½.

á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼€ÏÏ‡á½³Ï€Î»Î¿Ï…Ï„Î¿Î½, sc. Ï€á½³Î¼ÏˆÎ±Ï„Îµ or the like, to be supplied from á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ„Îµá½·Î»Î·Ï„Îµ, as Î±á½Î´á¿¶ in O. T. 241 from á¼€Ï€Î±Ï…Î´á¿¶, Î´Îµá¿– in O. C. 1404 from Î¿á½Îº á¼”Î¾ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹, á¼•ÎºÎ±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ in Ant. 263 from Î¿á½Î´Îµá½·Ï‚.

á¼€ÏÏ‡á½³Ï€Î»Î¿Ï…Ï„Î¿Î½, â€˜master of my possessionsâ€™; cp. á¼€ÏÏ‡á½³Î»Î±Î¿Ï‚, á¼€ÏÏ‡á½³Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï‚ ( Pind. P. 9. 58). Others understand, â€˜having ancient wealth,â€™=á¼€ÏÏ‡Î±Î¹á½¹Ï€Î»Î¿Ï…Ï„Î¿Î½. ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î·Î½, as restoring its fortunes, á¼€Ï€Î¿ÎºÎ±Î¸Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½±Î½Ï„Î±.

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½´Î½, announcing a new comer: 1422: O. C. 549 n.

Î¸Ï…Ïá¿¶Î½ is perhaps best taken as denoting the quarter whence the sound strikes the ear, so that it goes with Î±á¼°ÏƒÎ¸á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ (â€˜hear from the doorsâ€™). I should agree with the schol. in governing Î¸Ï…Ïá¿¶Î½ by á¼”Î½Î´Î¿Î½, did not the wide separation of the words make this so awkward. When Sophocles places a genitive long before the preposition which governs it, the genitive is usu. causal; and, as this sense is readily perceived, the delay of the prep. then matters less. See, e.g., 578 f. Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï…...Î¿á½•Î½ÎµÎº): O. T. 857 f. Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá½·Î±Ï‚...Î¿á½•Î½ÎµÎº): Ph. 598 f. Ï„á½·Î½Î¿Ï‚ ...Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½.

All three actors now leave the scene. Orestes and Pylades go to Agamemnon's grave,â€”departing, probably, by the entrance on the spectators' right. The Paedagogus leaves by the entrance on the left,â€”to await the moment for seeking admission to the house (v. 660).â€”It might, indeed, be inferred from Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïá½½Î¼ÎµÎ¸) (83) that the old man goes with the youths to their task; but the word need not imply more than his participation in the plan. while verses 73â€”75 seem clearly to indicate that he separates from his companions. When they have gone, Electra enters from the house.

A Î¸Ïá¿†Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½á¿†Ï‚, or lyric lament delivered by an actor alone. as dist. from the joint ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚ of actor and Chorus (121 n.).

Verses 86â€”102 form a Ïƒá½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î¼Î±,=vv. 103â€”120 (á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ïƒá½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î¼Î±). If the text is sound, the correspondence is not exact, since the dimeter in v. 99 answers to a monometer in v. 116. These anapaests are, however, of the type usually known as â€˜freeâ€™ or â€˜melic,â€™ as having more of a lyric character than the regular anapaests of the marching-songs (like those of the Parodos in the Ajax): see W. á½¦ Ï†á½±Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î³Î½á½¸Î½: the Sun-god abhors impurity ( O. T. 1425 ff.). So too the Î±á¼°Î¸á½µÏ is á¼Î³Î½á½¹Ï‚ ( Aesch. P. Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½°Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ â€¦ á¾”ÏƒÎ¸Î¿Ï…. Each of these two verses is an anapaestic dimeter lacking one long syllable (â€˜catalecticâ€™), i.e., a â€˜paroemiac.â€™ Two successive paroemiacs were admissible only in anapaests of this â€˜freeâ€™ or lyric character (n. on 86â€”120). These paroemiacs are purely spondaic; as â€˜freeâ€™ anapaests also admitted the converse license, of resolving the long syllables, except the last, of the paroemiac ( I. T. 130 Ï€á½¹Î´Î± Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½Î¹Î¿Î½ á½…ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î½ á½Ïƒá½·Î±Ï‚). Synesius, the bishop of Ptolemais, composed his fifth hymn wholly in these spondaic paroemiacs, a weighty and solemn measure; á½™Î¼Î½á½½Î¼ÎµÎ½ ÎºÎ¿á¿¦ÏÎ¿Î½ ÎºÎ¿á½»ÏÎ±Ï‚, | Î½á½»Î¼Ï†Î±Ï‚ Î¿á½ Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†ÎµÏ…Î¸Îµá½·ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, Îº.Ï„.Î». Line 90

Ï€Î»Î·Î³á½°Ï‚ must be preferred to Ï€Î»Î±Î³á½°Ï‚ here, unless we are to write Î³á¾¶Ï‚ (in 87), etc. As a rule, certainly, Doricism is a mark of lyric (as dist. from marching) anapaests; see Ant., append. p. 248, and cp. But the fact that these anapaests, though lyric in general character, precede the first lyrics of the Chorus, may have led the poet to prefer Attic forms, as in the anapaestic Parodos of the Ajax (134 ff., where Ï€Î»Î·Î³á½´ occurs in 137).

Electra invokes, (1) the house of Hades and his bride Persephone, in which the spirit of Agamemnon now dwells; (2) Hermes, who, as ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î¿Ï€Î¿Î¼Ï€á½¹Ï‚, conducted him thither,â€”and who will also guide the avengers on their way (1395 f.); (3) á¼ˆÏá½±, the imprecation uttered by the victim upon his murderers,â€”the personified curse, here conceived as a supernatural power (Ï€á½¹Ï„Î½Î¹Î±), which calls the Erinyes into action; and (4) the Erinyes themselves.

These much-impugned words appear genuine. The murder has been prompted by the guilty love: Î´á½¹Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ á½ Ï†Ïá½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, á¼”ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á½ ÎºÏ„Îµá½·Î½Î±Ï‚ (197). In Electra's thought, they are inseparable. The allusion to the love follows the reference to the murder, because she regards it as the crowning outrage (271 Ï„á½´Î½ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„Î±á½·Î±Î½ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Î½) that Clytaemnestra still lives with Aegisthus. Bloodshed was not the only sin which the Erinyes punished. They were the embodied sanctions of natural law, and every crime against the family came within their cognisance. (See Introd. to Homer, p. 51, Â§ 13.) Indeed, Electra herself speaks of the unhallowed union as a special provocation to those Avengers: 275 f. á¼¡ Î´â€™ á½§Î´Îµ Ï„Î»á½µÎ¼Ï‰Î½ á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ Ï„á¿· Î¼Î¹á½±ÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎ¹ | Î¾á½»Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„), á¼˜ÏÎ¹Î½á½ºÎ½ Î¿á½”Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á¼ÎºÏ†Î¿Î²Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î·.

á¼€Î¸Îµá½½Ï„Î±Ï„Î±: cp. 1181 (n.).

ÎºÎ±Îºá¾· â€¦ Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá½¶ Ï€Ïá½¹Î´Î¿Ï„Î¿Î½, betrayed (to death) by a dastardly hand. Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ïá½¶, following á¼€Ï€á½±Ï„Î±Î¹Ï‚, denotes the violent deed. Sophocles thinks of both Clytaemnestra and Aegisthus as active agents in the murder (99 ÏƒÏ‡á½·Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹). This is against understanding, â€˜betrayed (by her) to (his) hand.â€™

á½¡Ï‚ is properly an exclamation (â€˜how!â€™), as in á½¡Ï‚ á½¤Ï†ÎµÎ»Î¿Î½: here it stands, like utinam, with the optat. á½ Ï„á½±Î´Îµ Ï€Î¿Ïá½¼Î½ might refer to Clytaemnestra (for the masc., cp. Ant. 464 n.), but is rather general, including both the authors of the crime.

Îµá¼´ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Ï‚, like Tr. 809Îµá¼° Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Ï‚ Î´), á¼Ï€Îµá½»Ï‡Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹: Aegisthus and Clytaemnestra are the rulers of Mycenae. Cp. Eur. Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ â€ Î³á½¹Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î»Î¹Ï„Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½. The strophic verse (123) probably represents the true metre: Ï„á½±ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á½§Î´â€™ á¼€Îºá½¹ÏÎµÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ Î¿á¼°Î¼Ï‰Î³á½±Î½. On this point most modern critics are agreed, though they differ as to whether the verse should be considered glyconic or dactylic. But the correction of v. 139 remains quite uncertain. Many edd. have received Hermann's ingenious emendation, Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î³á½¹Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Î¿á½”Ï„) á¼„Î½Ï„Î±Î¹Ï‚. Doubtless Î‘ÎÎ¤Î‘Î™Î£ could easily have generated Î›Î™Î¤Î‘Î™Î£. Acc. to the version followed by Sophocles, Agamemnon had four daughters, Iphigeneia, Electra, Chrysothemis, Iphianassa. Orestes is conceived as pining in exile for the moment when he shall return as an avenger. Cp. 171 á¼€Îµá½¶ Î¼á½²Î½ Î³á½°Ï Ï€Î¿Î¸Îµá¿–: 602 Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ„Ï…Ï‡á¿† Ï„Ïá½·Î²ÎµÎ¹ Î²á½·Î¿Î½. Hermann, taking á¼€Ï‡á½³Ï‰Î½ as gen. pl. of á¼„Ï‡Î¿Ï‚, joined it with ÎºÏÏ…Ï€Ï„á¾·: semota a doloribus in iuventa felix. Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±, â€˜assigning,â€™ or â€˜committing,â€™ it to Zeus. The verb is used as in Î½á½³Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ±Î½ ( Tr. 1238) or Î½á½³Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î³á½³ÏÎ± ( O. C. 1396) Ï„Î¹Î½á½·. Wrath against evildoers is an attribute and a prerogative of Zeus, to whom the injured should leave the task of inflicting retribution. As the avenger of blood, Zeus was styled á¼€Î»á½±ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Ï, á¼€Î»Î¹Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚, Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¼Î½Î±á¿–Î¿Ï‚, Ï„Î¹Î¼Ï‰Ïá½¹Ï‚.

Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏá½±Ï‡Î¸ÎµÎ¿ (Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚) Î¿á½“Ï‚ á¼Ï‡Î¸Î±á½·ÏÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ á¼Ï€Î¹Î»á½±Î¸Î¿Ï… (Î±á½Ï„á¿¶Î½). For Î¿á¼·Ï‚ (by attraction, for Î¿á½•Ï‚), cp. H. 3. 5. 18 Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î¿á¼·Ï‚ Îµá¼¶Ï‡ÎµÎ½ á¾”ÎµÎ¹. The clauses are co-ordinate, but the emphasis is upon Î¼á½´ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏá½±Ï‡Î¸ÎµÎ¿. â€˜Without forgetting thy foes, refrain from excess of wrath against them.â€™ The Chorus allow that, as Electra has said (145), she cannot forget the murder of her father. Î¼á½µÎ¸â€™ Î¿á¼·Ï‚ á¼Ï‡Î¸Î±á½·ÏÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏá½±Ï‡Î¸ÎµÎ¿ Î¼á½µÏ„â€™ á¼Ï€Î¹Î»á½±Î¸Î¿Ï…Â·
