Line 721

á¼”Ï‡ÏÎ¹Î¼Ï€Ï„â€™ á¼€Îµá½¶ Ïƒá½»ÏÎ¹Î³Î³Î±, brought the nave of his (left) wheel close to the post at each successive turning. Ïƒá¿¦ÏÎ¹Î³Î¾ (â€˜pipeâ€™) is strictly the opening in the nave (á¼¡ á½€Ï€á½´ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï‡Î¿á¿¦, schol. on 716) which forms the socket of the axle; Suppl. 181 Ïƒá½»ÏÎ¹Î³Î³ÎµÏ‚ Î¿á½ ÏƒÎ¹Î³á¿¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€Î¾Î¿Î½á½µÎ»Î±Ï„Î¿Î¹ (the sockets of the whirling axles). Here it is a synonym for the Ï‡Î½á½¹Î· (717) or nave itself. That part of the wheel is rightly named here, because it projects slightly. Thus in v. 745 it is the Ï‡Î½á½¹Î· that strikes the post. For á¼”Ï‡ÏÎ¹Î¼Ï€Ï„) cp. Il. 23. 334Ï„á¿· Ïƒá½º Î¼á½±Î»â€™ á¼Î³Ï‡Ïá½·Î¼ÏˆÎ±Ï‚ á¼Î»á½±Î±Î½ ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ´á½¸Î½ á¼…ÏÎ¼Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚.

Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¸Î½ Î´â€™ á¼€Î½Îµá½¶Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». In a Ï„á½³Î¸ÏÎ¹Ï€Ï€Î¿Î½ the four horses were harnessed abreast. The two in the middle were under the yoke (Î¶á½»Î³Î¹Î¿Î¹), which was affixed to the pole (á¿¥Ï…Î¼á½¹Ï‚), and drew by the yoke-collars (Î»á½³Ï€Î±Î´Î½Î±ï¼‰ only, not being in traces. They were called respectively á½ Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¸Ï‚ and á½ Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½¹Ï‚ (schol. Nub. 122). The two outside horses drew by traces (ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏÎ±á½·) only, attached to their collars, and fastened to the á¼„Î½Ï„Ï…Î¾ of the car at its lower edge: hence ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏÎ±á¿–Î¿Î¹, ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏÎ±Ï†á½¹ÏÎ¿Î¹. In turning from right to left, the righthand trace-horse had most work to do; hence Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¹ÏƒÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚, fig., a strong helper at need ( Ant. 140 n.). The Homeric poems speak of one trace-horse besides the two yoke-horses (Ï€Î±Ïá½µÎ¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚, the traces being Ï€Î±ÏÎ·Î¿Ïá½·Î±Î¹): Il. 8. 87; 16. 152, Il. 471: Od. 4. 590.

Sophocles has in mind the words of Nestor to Antilochus, Il. 23. 336Ï„á½¸Î½ Î´ÎµÎ¾Î¹á½¸Î½ á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Î½ | Îºá½³Î½ÏƒÎ±Î¹ á½Î¼Î¿ÎºÎ»á½µÏƒÎ±Ï‚, Îµá¼¶Î¾Î±á½· Ï„á½³ Î¿á¼± á¼¡Î½á½·Î± Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½·Î½Â· | á¼Î½ Î½á½»ÏƒÏƒá¿ƒ Î´á½³ Ï„Î¿Î¹ á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï‚ á¼€ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½¸Ï‚ á¼Î³Ï‡ÏÎ¹Î¼Ï†Î¸á½µÏ„Ï‰, | á½¡Ï‚ á¼„Î½ Ï„Î¿Î¹ Ï€Î»á½µÎ¼Î½Î· Î³Îµ Î´Î¿á½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ á¼„ÎºÏÎ¿Î½ á¼±Îºá½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ | Îºá½»ÎºÎ»Î¿Ï… Ï€Î¿Î¹Î·Ï„Î¿á¿–Î¿ (â€˜so that just the nave of the well-wrought wheel may seem to graze itâ€™).

725 Ï€á¿¶Î»Î¿Î¹ Î²á½·á¾³ Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½Â· á¼Îº Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï†á¿†Ï‚

Line 726

Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Îº.Ï„.Î»., â€˜finishing the sixth and now (entering upon) the seventh round.â€™ The more general sense of Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„<*>ÎµÏ‚ (â€˜doingâ€™) is evolved from the special; cp. on ÎºÏá½»ÏˆÎ¿Î½ in 436.â€”Nauck finds the reading suspicious, â€˜since Ï€á¿¶Î»Î¿Ï‚ is almost always fem.â€™ It often is so (705 n.); but often, too, masc.: e.g. Aesch. Ag. 1641ï¼ˆÎºÏÎ¹Î¸á¿¶Î½Ï„Î± Ï€á¿¶Î»Î¿Î½), Aesch. Ch. 749, Xen. Eq. 1. 1.

The Aenian, closely followed by the others, had just completed his sixth Î´á½·Î±Ï…Î»Î¿Ï‚, or double course, in the hippodrome: i.e., he had just passed, for the sixth time, round the goal nearest to the starting-place, and was on the point of beginning his seventh course. Just as he was passing the goal, his horses bolted. Hence he could not work them quite round into the track. They turned out of the left-ward curve (á¼Î¾ á½‘Ï€Î¿ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï†á¿†Ï‚), and ran straight on. Meanwhile, one of the two Libyan chariots had swept round the goal in a wider circle, on the Aenian's right. The Aenian's horses dashed head-foremost into the Libyan's team, striking it on the left side.

In the four - horse chariot - race at Olympia the number of double courses was twelve. Hence the goal farthest from the starting-place is Î´Ï‰Î´ÎµÎºá½±Î³Î½Î±Î¼Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½... Ï„á½³ÏÎ¼Î± Î´Ïá½¹Î¼Î¿Ï… | á¼µÏ€Ï€Ï‰Î½ ( Pind. O. 3. 33: cp. Pind. O. 2. 55, Pind. O. 6. 75, Pind. P. 5. 33). If the á¼±Ï€Ï€Î¹Îºá½¸Î½ (=4 stadia) be taken as the length of one double course in the hippodrome, twelve such courses give about 51/2 English miles. (Cp. art. Hippodromus in Smith's Dict. Ant., 3rd ed., p. 965 a.ï¼‰

á¼Î¾ á¼‘Î½á½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿¦. Other chariots were close upon the Aenian and the Barcaean. Î³Î½Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î´) Îº.Ï„.Î». At the moment when the Aenian ran into the Barcaean, the Athenian was among the foremost drivers behind these two. On seeing the crash, he drew aside, reining in his horses, and allowed the chariots behind him to rush past in the middle of the course. They were all wrecked or disabled. á¼”ÏƒÏ‡Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ corresponds with á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Î´) (736): he was then last, indeed; but, when he saw that only one competitor was left, he pressed to the front.

á½‘ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ explains why he was á¼”ÏƒÏ‡Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚: he was purposely keeping his horses behind; and Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰Î½, again, gives the motive of this; because he relied on the finish. Îºá½±ÏÎ± Ï€ÏÎ¿Î²á½±Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î».: â€˜showing his head in front of the (two) chariots.â€™ The neck-and-neck race is described as it would appear to a spectator at one side of the hippodrome, who saw the drivers in profile. Each charioteer is leaning forward in his car (as so often seen on vases). The head, now of one driver, now of the other, would be seen in front.â€”Not: â€˜bringing the head of his equipage in front (of the other team).â€™

For Ï€ÏÎ¿Î²á½±Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ in partitive appos. with the subject of á¼ Î»Î±Ï…Î½á½³Ï„Î·Î½, cp. Phaedr. 248 A (Î±á¼± ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î±á½¶) Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹,...á¼‘Ï„á½³ÏÎ± Ï€Ïá½¸ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼‘Ï„á½³ÏÎ±Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÎ¹ÏÏ‰Î¼á½³Î½Î· Î³ÎµÎ½á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹: and n. on Ant. 259 ff.

á¼ Î»Î±Ï…Î½á½³Ï„Î·Î½, Ï„á½¹Ï„â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚, á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Î¸â€™ á¼…Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚

Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚. Six rounds still remained to be run when Orestes and the Athenian were left alone (see on 726). The word á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï„Î± is vague, but probably the disaster of Orestes is conceived as happening in the middle of the last (or twelfth) round.

á¼€ÏƒÏ†Î±Î»Îµá¿–Ï‚ is proleptic, â€˜in safetyâ€™: it is needless to write á¼€ÏƒÏ†Î±Î»á½µÏ‚.

á½ ÏÎ¸Î¿á¿¦Î¸), â€˜had a prosperous courseâ€™: cp. Ant. 675Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î´â€™ á½€ÏÎ¸Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½, â€˜of those whose course is fairâ€™ (n.). Line 743

Î»á½»Ï‰Î½ á¼¡Î½á½·Î±Î½ á¼€ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏá½°Î½. He was turning sharply round the goal from right to left, and was therefore pulling the rein of the left trace-horse. He slackened this rein a moment too soon, thus letting the horse draw with more force. The effect was to create an angular velocity, which brought the left wheel into collision with the goal. See note in Appendix. The notion that Î»á½»Ï‰Î½ has supplanted a word of the opposite sense (â€˜tighteningâ€™) appears mistaken.

Line 745

Ï‡Î½á½¹Î±Ï‚. The wooden nave (717), in which the axle turned, was broken across (Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ±Ï‚) by striking the ÏƒÏ„á½µÎ»Î·, and the left wheel came off. Ï‡Î½á½¹Î±Ï‚ might also denote the end of the axle itself (á¼€ÎºÏÎ±Î¾á½¹Î½Î¹Î¿Î½): but it seems needless to assume this sense, which is less suited to Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ ( Tr. 781Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Ï… | ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î±ÏƒÏ€Î±Ïá½³Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚). á¼€Î½Ï„á½»Î³Ï‰Î½, the â€˜rimâ€™ or rail, surmounting a barrier or breastwork, often of osier trellis-work, which protected the front, and both sides, of the chariot; the plur., as in Il. 5. 728Î´Î¿Î¹Î±á½¶ Î´á½² Ï€ÎµÏá½·Î´ÏÎ¿Î¼Î¿Î¹ á¼„Î½Ï„Ï…Î³á½³Ï‚ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹ (i.e., one on each side); Ai. 1030.It did not reach higher than the driver's waist, and was sometimes lower. Î´Î¹ÎµÏƒÏ€á½±ÏÎ·ÏƒÎ±Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î´Ïá½¹Î¼Î¿Î½, â€˜were scattered into the middle of the courseâ€™; i.e., left the track in which the race was being run (the â€˜courseâ€™ in the narrower sense), and rushed on to the open ground between this track and the spectators. Î´Î¹ÎµÏƒÏ€á½±ÏÎ·ÏƒÎ±Î½ cannot be satisfactorily explained on the assumption that all four horses remained harnessed to the car. But we need not assume that Orestes was entangled in the reins of all four. We may suppose, then, that, when the left wheel came off, the left tracehorse, plunging wildly, broke his traces, and freed himself. No mishap to the Î¶Ï…Î³á½¹Î½ is noticed, and the two yokehorses, at any rate, probably remained together. Unless they broke the pole, they would still drag the disabled car. Line 752

Ï†Î¿ÏÎ¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½–Î´Î±Ï‚, â€˜dashed to the groundâ€™: cp. I. T. 49 Î²ÎµÎ²Î»Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½–Î´Î±Ï‚. [Not, â€˜dragged upon the groundâ€™ (Campb.), which would be Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½”Î´ÎµÎ¹.] These words can be taken in two ways: I prefer the first. (1) With reference to his fall from the chariot. The people speak of his mishap as a whole, not merely of what he is suffering at the moment. (2) With reference to what occurs while he is being dragged; he is dashed earthwards (after being tossed upward). But this would be most awkward, when the mention of his being tossed upward follows. Eur. , where he speaks of men dragged on the ground by their chariot-horses, naturally says, â€˜tossed up and downâ€™ (not â€˜down and upâ€™): Suppl. 689 á¼¢ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼„Î½Ï‰ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îºá½±Ï„Ï‰ Ï†Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ | á¼±Î¼Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½.

á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï„): the first á¼„Î»Î»Î¿|Ï„Îµ is omitted: Eur. Hec. 28ÎºÎµá¿–Î¼Î±Î¹ Î´â€™ á¼Ï€â€™ á¼€ÎºÏ„Î±á¿–Ï‚, á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï„â€™ á¼Î½ Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï… Ïƒá½±Î»á¿³.

764 f. The word Î´ÎµÏƒÏ€á½¹Ï„Î±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ would usu. imply that the speaker was a slave. The women of the Chorus are free (1227 Ï€Î¿Î»á½·Ï„Î¹Î´ÎµÏ‚), and it has been suggested that the poet forgot this. Line 766

á½¦ Î–Îµá¿¦. Clytaemnestra regretted her failure to destroy Orestes in childhood (296 f.). But the poet is true to nature in blending some touch of maternal grief with her sense of gain.

Line 797

Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½ á¼‚Î½ á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï‚. Clyt. refers to Electra's words, Ï€ÎµÏ€Î±á½»Î¼ÎµÎ¸â€™ á¼¡Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚: â€˜If you have indeed silenced her, then you would deserve much,â€™ etc. A protasis formed by Îµá¼° and a past tense of the indic. is sometimes thus combined with an apodosis formed by the optat. and á¼„Î½. In such cases the past tense usu. denotes an actual fact, or what is assumed to be such. Thus O. C. 974 ff. Îµá¼° Î´)..á¼¦Î»Î¸Î¿Î½,.. Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ á¼‚Î½..Ïˆá½³Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚; Thuc. 3. 40Îµá¼° Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½—Ï„Î¿Î¹ á½€ÏÎ¸á¿¶Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½³ÏƒÏ„Î·ÏƒÎ±Î½ (granting that they were right), á½‘Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ Î¿á½ Ï‡ÏÎµá½¼Î½ á¼„ÏÏ‡Î¿Î¹Ï„Îµ. Line 814

Î´Î¿Ï…Î»Îµá½»ÎµÎ¹Î½: cp. 1192: 597 Î´ÎµÏƒÏ€á½¹Ï„Î¹Î½. She was treated like a slave (190 ff.).

Ï€á½±Î»Î¹Î½ has been suspected, but is explained by the context. In fact, her servitude had never ceased, and could not be said to recommence. But in imagination, so long as Orestes lived, she could behold a deliverer. From those bright dreams she must now go back to a slavery without hope.

Line 823823-870

Kommos. 1st strophe, 823â€”835, =1st antistr., 836â€”848: 2nd str., 849â€”859, =2nd antistr., 860â€”870. For metres see Metrical Analysis. Changes of person occur within a verse (as in 829 ff., Î—Î›. Ï†Îµá¿¦. Î§ÎŸ. Î¼Î·Î´á½²Î½ Î¼á½³Î³â€™ á¼€á¿£Ïƒá¿ƒÏ‚. Î—Î›. á¼€Ï€Î¿Î»Îµá¿–Ï‚. Î§ÎŸ. Ï€á¿¶Ï‚; ). This indicates that the Chorus is here represented by the coryphaeus; it is, in fact, a lyric duet between the leader and Electra. Similar duets occur in O. T. 649â€”697 and O. C. 510â€”548, passages which further resemble this as being ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼Î¿á½· inserted in á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïƒá½¹Î´Î¹Î±: also in the parodos of the O. C.(as at 178 ff.), and its exodos (as at 1677 ff.): and in Ph. 1081â€”1217 (as at 1184 f.).

These lyrics mark the climax of Electra's grief. The comforter vainly seeks to rouse her from despair.

Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ Îº.Ï„.Î». â€˜where are they?â€™ means here, â€˜what are they doing, â€”if they see this, and do not punish?â€™ It is the part of the Sun-god to reveal guilt (cp. n. on 424 f.), and of the thunderbolts to smite it.

Line 836

Î¿á¼¶Î´Î± Î³á½°Ï Îº.Ï„.Î».: â€˜Nay, (I can still offer thee comfort;) for I know that AmphiaraÃ¼s, like Agamemnon, was betrayed to death by a false wife; and yet now he is a great spiritual force beneath the earth, and is revered among men.â€™ Although Orestes is dead, Agamemnon may still be honoured. The Chorus do not directly hint a belief that he can still be avenged,â€”as AmphiaraÃ¼s was. Electra then seizes on this point of contrast, AmphiaraÃ¼s found an avenger; her father cannot now find one.

á¼ˆÎ¼Ï†Î¹á½±ÏÎµÏ‰Î½, scanned Â¯Ë˜Ë˜Â¯, as in O. C. 1313(n.): á¼„Î½Î±ÎºÏ„Î±, as the seer Teiresias is so called, O. T. 284(n.). AmphiaraÃ¼s, the Argive seer and warrior, married EriphylÃ¨, sister of Adrastus, king of Argos. He had sworn to abide by her decision in any difference between himself and her brother, with whom he had formerly been at feud ( Apollod. 3. 6. 2). When Polyneices sought Argive aid against Thebes, AmphiaraÃ¼s opposed the enterprise, foreseeing a fatal issue. Polyneices then bribed EriphylÃ¨ with a golden necklace, and she persuaded her husband to join the expedition. The Argives were routed by the Thebans. In the flight, AmphiaraÃ¼s was approaching the river Ismenus, near Thebes, when the earth, riven by a thunderbolt, swallowed him up, with his chariot: cp. fr. 873. Sophocles wrote an á¼˜ÏÎ¹Ï†á½»Î»Î·, and also a satyric á¼ˆÎ¼Ï†Î¹á½±ÏÎµÏ‰Ï‚.

á¼•ÏÎºÎµÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÏÏ…Ï†Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá¿¶Î½Â· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î½á¿¦Î½ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Î³Î±á½·Î±Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 837

Ï‡ÏÏ…ÏƒÎ¿Î´á½³Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼•ÏÎºÎµÏƒÎ¹, nets, or snares, of golden links; i.e., the toils of fate into which he was drawn through the necklace with which his wife was bribed. (Not, â€˜the snare laid for her by the necklaceâ€™; she knew what was to come.) The epithet marks the figurative sense of á¼•ÏÎºÎµÏƒÎ¹ (as a ship is Î»Î¹Î½á½¹Ï€Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ á½„Ï‡Î·Î¼Î±, Aesch. P. In Aesch. Theb. 587 f. AmphiaraÃ¼s says, Ï„á½µÎ½Î´Îµ Ï€Î¹Î±Î½á¿¶ Ï‡Î¸á½¹Î½Î±, | Î¼á½±Î½Ï„Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎµÎºÎµÏ…Î¸á½¼Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î»ÎµÎ¼á½·Î±Ï‚ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½¹Ï‚. Pausanias (9. 8. 3) saw near Thebes the enclosed and sacred spot where the earth had opened.

Some vase-paintings, representing the departure of AmphiaraÃ¼s for Thebes, show EriphylÃ¨ carrying the bribe in her hand. In one of these, on a very ancient vase from Caere, it appears as a necklace of large white pearls (Baumeister, Denkm. p. 67): in another, on a lekythos from Cervetri (Roscher, Lex.p. 295), it is a collar, with projecting rays.

Line 841

Ï€á½±Î¼ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î¿Ï‚=Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ±Î½ Ï„á½´Î½ ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½´Î½ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ (cp. á¼„ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î¿Ï‚). The mind of AmphiaraÃ¼s acts upon men through his oracles as fully as if he were alive. In the popular belief, the ordinary shades of the departed had either no intelligence or a feeble one. Thus Teiresias is an exception ( Od. 10. 495): Ï„á¿· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„ÎµÎ¸Î½Î·á¿¶Ï„Î¹ Î½á½¹Î¿Î½ Ï€á½¹ÏÎµ Î ÎµÏÏƒÎµÏ†á½¹Î½ÎµÎ¹Î± | Î¿á¼´á¿³ Ï€ÎµÏ€Î½á¿¦ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹Â· Ï„Î¿á½¶ Î´á½² ÏƒÎºÎ¹Î±á½¶ á¼€á¿“ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½. It was felt difficult to conceive mind apart from its supposed physical basis, the Ï†Ïá½³Î½ÎµÏ‚ or diaphragm: cp. Leaf on Il. 23. 104.â€”The scholia recognise this explanation of Ï€á½±Î¼ÏˆÏ…Ï‡Î¿Ï‚, but suggest also two others, both untenable: (1) â€˜ruling over all the shadesâ€™: or (2) â€˜possessing his life Î´Î¹á½° Ï€Î±Î½Ï„á½¹Ï‚,â€™ i.e. â€˜immortal.â€™

The cult of AmphiaraÃ¼s had its chief seat in Boeotia, but afterwards spread thence to Argos, and throughout Greece. He was a chthonian deity, like Melampus; associated with Dionysus, and then with the Apollinar Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Î¹Îºá½µ. The á¼ˆÎ¼Ï†Î¹á½±ÏÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½ near Thebes, a dream-oracle, was consulted by Mardonius ( Her. 8. 134). In later times the shrine near Oropus was more famous ( I. Paus. 34. 2).

Line 842

Ï†Îµá¿¦.

Ï†Îµá¿¦ Î´á¿†Ï„). Electra's cry, Ï†Îµá¿¦, is drawn from her by the thought that, while AmphiaraÃ¼s has honour, her father's spirit is unhonoured. á¼Î´á½±Î¼Î· should be followed by a full stop, as in L; not by a query, as in the Aldine,â€”a punctuation suggested by Î½Î±á½·. Electra is not asking a question; she is rejecting the consolation. Î¼ÎµÎ»á½³Ï„Ï‰Ï (only here): â€˜one who caredâ€™ for the dead,â€”an avenger (cp. 237 á¼€Î¼ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½). Suidas s.v., á½ á¼Ï€Î¹Î¼ÎµÎ»Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, á½ Ï„Î¹Î¼Ï‰ÏÎ¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á¿· Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½·. The conjecture Î½ÎµÎ¼á½³Ï„Ï‰Ï (a word applied to the avenging Zeus in Aesch. Th. 485) is less fitting. For the form, cp. also Î³ÎµÎ½á½³Ï„Ï‰Ï.

AmphiaraÃ¼s was avenged by his son Alcmaeon ,â€”the counterpart, in this story, of Orestes. Before setting out for Thebes, the seer had charged him with this duty. EriphylÃ¨, bribed once more, prevailed upon her son to lead the Epigoni against Thebes. After its fall, he returned to Argos, and slew her. Pursued by the Erinyes, he fled to Psophis in Arcadia, and there was purified. He was the subject of a play by Sophocles, and of two by Euripides,â€”the first, á½ Î´Î¹á½° Î¨Ï‰Ï†á¿–Î´Î¿Ï‚ (produced in 438 B.C.), dealing with his absolution, and the second, á½ Î´Î¹á½° ÎšÎ¿Ïá½·Î½Î¸Î¿Ï…, with a later episode. Acc. to a grammarian in Anecd. Oxon. II. p. 337, 4, the form of the name used by Eur. was á¼ˆÎ»ÎºÎ¼á½³Ï‰Î½.

Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½»ÏÏ„á¿³ â€¦ Î±á¼°á¿¶Î½Î¹. The traditional text is Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½»ÏÏ„á¿³ Ï€Î±Î¼Î¼á½µÎ½á¿³ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½ | Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á¿¶Î½ ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³Î½á¿¶Î½ Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï‡á½³Ï‰Î½ (or á¼€Ï‡Î±á½·Ï‰Î½). Hermann substitutes Î±á¼°á¿¶Î½Î¹ for á¼€Ï‡á½³Ï‰Î½, regarding the latter as a gloss upon the adjectives. Dindorf, accepting Î±á¼°á¿¶Î½Î¹, rejects Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½, reading Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½»ÏÏ„á¿³ Ï€Î±Î¼Î¼á½µÎ½á¿³ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á¿¶Î½ | ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³Î½á¿¶Î½ Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï‡á½³Ï‰Î½ Î±á¼°á¿¶Î½Î¹. But the antistrophic verse (863), Ï„Î¼Î·Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á½Î»ÎºÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼Î³Îºá¿¦ÏÏƒÎ±Î¹, makes á¼€Ï‡á½³Ï‰Î½ less metrically probable; on Dindorf's view, we might rather suggest á¼€Ï‡Î¸á¿¶Î½ (cp. 204 á¼”ÎºÏ€Î±Î³Î»â€™ á¼„Ï‡Î¸Î·). And Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½, as Hermann saw, is not likely to have been interpolated (â€˜Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½, si quidquam, sanum estâ€™). For other conjectures, see Appendix.

The literal sense then is:â€”â€˜(I know this) by a life which, through all the months, is a turbid torrent of many things dread and horrible.â€™ Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½»ÏÏ„á¿³ seems rightly explained in one scholium as Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Ïƒá½»ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï„á½° ÎºÎ±Îºá½±: i.e., it has an active sense, like Ï‡Î±Î»Îºá½¹Ï€Î»Î±ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï‚ (484 n.), á¼€Î¼Ï†á½·Ï€Î»Î±ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï‚ ( Ph. 688), Ï€Î±Î½á½±Î»Ï‰Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (á¼„Ï„Î·, Aesch. Ag. 361). The genitive, Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á¿¶Î½ ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³Î½á¿¶Î½ Ï„), may depend upon it, as in Soph. Ant. 1184 f. Î¸Îµá¾¶Ï‚..Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½µÎ³Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï‚=Î¸Îµá½°Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ·Î³Î¿ÏÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ±. But we might also join the genitive with Î±á¼°á¿¶Î½Î¹, as=â€˜a life ofâ€™ (made up of) these things. For the verb Ïƒá½»ÏÏ‰ in ref. to a torrent, cp. Ar. Eq. 527Î´Î¹á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€Ï†ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½ Ï€ÎµÎ´á½·Ï‰Î½ á¼”ÏÏÎµÎ¹, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎµÏ‰Ï‚ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ïƒá½»ÏÏ‰Î½ | á¼Ï†á½¹ÏÎµÎ¹ Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î´Ïá¿¦Ï‚: Plut. Mor.p. 5 F Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¼Î¿Ï‚ Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á½±ÏÏÎ¿Ï… Î´á½·ÎºÎ·Î½ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Ïƒá½»ÏÏ‰Î½. Thus Ï€Î±Î¼Î¼á½µÎ½á¿³ has a special point. The literal Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á½±ÏÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚ flows only in winter.

This view gives Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½»ÏÏ„á¿³ a more forcible and more poetical sense than if it be taken as=â€˜swept together from every side.â€™ The meaning then would be, â€˜a life, through all the months, of many dread horrors, accumulated from every quarter,â€™â€”the epithet Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½»ÏÏ„á¿³ being transferred from the troubles to the life itself. It would still, indeed, be possible to make Ï€Î±Î½Ïƒá½»ÏÏ„á¿³ active; â€˜a life which draws troubles together from all sidesâ€™; but such an active sense would be somewhat harsher, on this interpretation, than on that which supposes the image of a torrent.

á¼Î¸Ïá½µÎ½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚. The MS. reading, á¼ƒ Î¸ÏÎ¿Îµá¿–Ï‚, conflicts with the metre of the antistrophe (864), where the corresponding words are á¼ Î»á½½Î²Î±. In Ai. 582, where Î¸ÏÎ·Î½Îµá¿–Î½ is right, Î¸ÏÎ¿Îµá¿–Î½ was a v.l. (Paris A). The reasons for preferring á¼Î¸Ïá½µÎ½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ to á¼ƒ Î¸ÏÎ·Î½Îµá¿–Ï‚ are two. In 850â€”852 Electra refers to the woes which she has so long endured. The Chorus now reply, â€˜We have seen what thou wast mourning,â€™â€”â€˜the course of thy sorrow,â€™â€”through all those years (cp. 140 f.). Ï€á½±ÏÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ á¼”Ï„Î¹ Îº.Ï„.Î». The choice is between two readings; (1) Îµá½Ï€Î±Ï„ÏÎ¹Î´á¾¶Î½ á¼€ÏÏ‰Î³Î±á½·, and (2) Neue's correction, Îµá½Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½·Î´Ï‰Î½ Ï„) á¼€ÏÏ‰Î³Î±á½·. Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î´Ïá¿¶Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î»á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½â€™ á¼„Î½. Elmsley (on Eur. Med. 416 f., p. 151) remarked that the Attic poets seldom elide the Îµ of the 3rd pers. sing. before á¼„Î½: e.g. á¼”Î³ÏÎ±Ïˆâ€™ á¼„Î½, scripsissem, is easier to find than á¼”Î³ÏÎ±Ïˆâ€™ á¼„Î½, scripsisset. He does not add, however, that in respect to the weak (or â€˜firstâ€™) aorists there was a reason for it, viz., that á¼”Î³ÏÎ±Ïˆâ€™ á¼„Î½, when meant as the 3rd pers., was liable to be confused with the 1st, unless the context was decisive; a reason which did not apply to the strong aorists or imperfects, e.g. to á¼”Î»Î±Î¸â€™ á¼„Î½ or á¼Î»á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½â€™ á¼„Î½. Yet, even in regard to the first aor., there is at least one instance where the MSS. attest the elision of Îµ, and the sense confirms it; Ar. Plut. 1011 Î“Î¡...Î½Î·Ï„Ï„á½±ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ á¼‚Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†á½±Ï„Ï„Î¹Î¿Î½ á½‘Ï€ÎµÎºÎ¿Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÏ„Î¿. | Î§Î¡. á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï„â€™ á¼´ÏƒÏ‰Ï‚ á¾”Ï„Î·Ïƒâ€™ á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î´á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±: where Elmsley's correction á¾”Ï„Î·ÏƒÎµÎ½ for á¾”Ï„Î·Ïƒâ€™ á¼‚Î½, though not impossible, is improbable. Take, again, Eur. Ion 354 ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ Ï„Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼¥Î²Î·Ï‚, Îµá¼´Ï€ÎµÏ á¼¦Î½, Îµá¼¶Ï‡â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¼á½³Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½ (so the MSS.): where Îµá¼¶Ï‡ÎµÎ½ would be excessively harsh, while Elmsley's emendation, ÏƒÎ¿á½¶ Ï„Î±á½”Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½..Îµá¼¶Ï‡ÎµÎ½ Î¼á½³Ï„ÏÎ±, is clearly condemned by the plural.

It is quite true that such elision was rare; the Î½ á¼Ï†ÎµÎ»ÎºÏ…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Îºá½¹Î½ more usually averted it. The mistake is to deny that it was admissible. Porson's keen observation and fine instinct led him to no such rule; he found no offence (e.g.) in Eur. Hec. 1113 Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±Ïá½³ÏƒÏ‡â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¿á½ Î¼á½³ÏƒÏ‰Ï‚ á½…Î´Îµ ÎºÏ„á½»Ï€Î¿Ï‚ (Ï€Î±Ïá½³ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÎ½ MSS.; Ï€Î±Ïá½³ÏƒÏ‡â€™ á¼‚Î½ Heath).

But is á¼Î»á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½ÎµÎ½, the reading of the MSS., even tenable? Surely not. The sense required is: â€˜Nor, if she had done it, would she have escaped notice.â€™ But the words Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Î´Ïá¿¶Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î»á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½ÎµÎ½ could mean only one of two things: (1) â€˜nor, when she did it, was she escaping (or used she to escapeï¼‰ noticeâ€™: (2) â€˜nor, when she did it, was she in the way to escape noticeâ€™; cp. Eur. H. F. 537 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á¼„Î¼â€™ á¼”Î¸Î½á¿ƒÏƒÎºÎµ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½), á¼€Ï€Ï‰Î»Î»á½»Î¼Î·Î½ Î´â€™ á¼Î³á½½: â€˜my children were in peril of death,â€™ etc. That is: whichever shade of meaning were given to á¼Î»á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½ÎµÎ½, still Î´Ïá¿¶ÏƒÎ±, in the absence of anything to mark conditionality, would imply, not Îµá¼° á¼”Î´ÏÎ±, but á½…Ï„Îµ á¼”Î´ÏÎ±. Before Î´Ïá¿¶ÏƒÎ± can mean Îµá¼° á¼”Î´ÏÎ±, we must have á¼Î»á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½â€™ á¼„Î½, or some equivalent (as á¼”Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»Îµ Î»Î±Î½Î¸á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½), in the apodosis. Conversely, before the simple á¼Î»á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½ÎµÎ½ could have a conditional sense, we should require as protasis, not Î´Ïá¿¶ÏƒÎ±, but Îµá¼° á¼”Î´ÏÎ±.

If á¼Î»á½±Î½Î¸Î±Î½â€™ á¼„Î½ were incorrect (which has not been proved), I should read á¼”Î»Î·Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼„Î½ (cp. 1359).

Line 953

Ï€Ïá½±ÎºÏ„Î¿á¿¤, one who exacts a penalty; an avenger: as the Erinyes are Ï€Ïá½±ÎºÏ„Î¿ÏÎµÏ‚ Î±á¼µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ( Aesch. Eum. 319). At Athens the Ï€Ïá½±ÎºÏ„Î¿ÏÎµÏ‚ were officials who collected fines and penalties (á¼Ï€Î¹Î²Î¿Î»Î±á½·, Ï„Î¹Î¼á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±) imposed by law. We have a similar figurative use of a technical term in Soph. Ai. 508Î¼Î·Ï„á½³ÏÎ± | Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á¿¶Î½ á¼Ï„á¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ»Î·ÏÎ¿á¿¦Ï‡Î¿Î½: and in Aesch. Eum. 273 the word for an â€˜auditorâ€™ who examined the accounts of magistrates is applied to the king of the nether world; Î¼á½³Î³Î±Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï á¼Î¹Î´Î·Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ Îµá½”Î¸Ï…Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½. There are Shakespearian parallels; e.g., Lear (act 3, sc. 2, 59) calls the raging elements â€˜these dreadful summonersâ€™ (officers who warned offenders to appear in court): Hamlet (act 5, sc. 2, Aesch. Eum. 347) speaks of â€˜this fell sergeant, deathâ€™: and death is â€˜that fell arrest without all bailâ€™ (Sonn. 74, 1).

Î½á¿¦Î½ Î´â€™ á¼¡Î½á½·Îºâ€™ Î¿á½Îºá½³Ï„â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½, Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ïƒá½² Î´á½´ Î²Î»á½³Ï€Ï‰, ğŸ—©

Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ïƒá½² Î´á½´ Î²Î»á½³Ï€Ï‰: here Î´á½´, after á¼¡Î½á½·Îºâ€™ Î¿á½Îºá½³Ï„â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½, marks the next resource, just as in Ant. 173á¼Î³á½¼ ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î· Î´á½´..á¼”Ï‡Ï‰ follows á½…Ï„â€™ Î¿<*>Î½ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Î¹..á½¤Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿. 955 á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î¿Ï… Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…
Î¾á½ºÎ½ Ï„á¿‡Î´â€™ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á¿‡ Î¼á½´ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿ÎºÎ½á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ ÎºÏ„Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 956

ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿ÎºÎ½á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚. The clause á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿ÎºÎ½á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ denotes the object of the appeal implied in Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ïƒá½² Î´á½´ Î²Î»á½³Ï€Ï‰. Cp. Ar. Eq. 1255ÎºÎ±á½· Ïƒâ€™ Î±á¼°Ï„á¿¶ Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡á½», | á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±á½· ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Î¦Î±Î½á½¹Ï‚. This is the normal construction. The v. l. ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿ÎºÎ½á½µÏƒá¿ƒÏ‚ is also correct, but is less probable. Any verb can be followed by a â€˜finalâ€™ clause in the subjunctive, expressing the â€˜endâ€™ or purpose of the action, as á¼”ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ <*>Î½Î± á¼´Î´á¿ƒ. But a verb of endeavouring, praying, contriving, usually takes an â€˜objectâ€™ clause, expressing the object of the effort, with á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ (or á½¡Ï‚) and fut. indic.: as Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïá¾¶Ï„Î±Î¹ á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á½„ÏˆÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. Exceptions occur, as Xen. An. 5. 6.Â§ 21 Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Îµá¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î¹..á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á¼ÎºÏ€Î»Îµá½»Ïƒá¿ƒ á¼¡ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î¹á½±: Dem. or. 1 Â§ 2 Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á½±ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹..á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á¼Î½Î¸á½³Î½Î´Îµ Î²Î¿Î·Î¸á½µÏƒÎ·Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½´ Ï€á½±Î¸Î·Ï„Îµ Ï„Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½: but these are comparatively rare. After a verb of effort, the presumption is always in favour of the fut. indic. See Goodwin, Moods and Tenses (new ed.), Â§ 364.

Brunck's comment, â€˜soloece vulgo ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¿ÎºÎ½á½µÏƒá¿ƒÏ‚,â€™ alludes to the rule laid down by R. Dawes (ob. 1766) in Miscellanea Critica (p. 227), and once known as the canon Davesianus, that á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ could not be used with the first aor. subjunct. act. or midd. Among many examples that refute it are á¼ÎºÏ€Î»Îµá½»Ïƒá¿ƒ in the passage just quoted from Xen. (the fut. being á¼ÎºÏ€Î»Îµá½»ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹), and ÎºÎ»Î±á½»ÏƒÏ‰ in 1122 (the fut. being ÎºÎ»Î±á½»ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹).

Î‘á¼´Î³Î¹ÏƒÎ¸Î¿Î½Â· Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Î³á½±Ï ÏƒÎµ Î´Îµá¿– ÎºÏá½»Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¼â€™ á¼”Ï„Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 957

ÎºÏá½»Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½: cp. Ph. 915Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½ ÏƒÎµ ÎºÏá½»ÏˆÏ‰.â€”Nauck follows Wunder in rejecting this verse, because (1) Ï„á½¸Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± can mean no one but Aegisthus; (2) Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Î³á½±Ï ÏƒÎµ Î´Îµá¿– ÎºÏá½»Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¼â€™ á¼”Ï„Î¹ would have point only if Chrysothemis did not already know the guilt of Aegisthus; (3) ÏƒÎµ and Î¼Îµ cause ambiguity. We may reply: (1) The mention of the murderer's name, which Electra has hitherto uttered only in her solitary lament (98), is forcible here; and the emphatic place given to it is in the manner of Sophocles (cp. 1507 ÎºÏ„Îµá½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½: Ant. 46á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½¹Î½). (2) The words Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Î³á½±Ï ÏƒÎµ Îº.Ï„.Î». refer, of course, to the purpose which Electra now disclosesâ€”not to the guilt of Aegisthus. (3) The formal ambiguity of ÏƒÎµ..Î¼Îµ is only such as occurs in Ant. 288á¼¢ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï„Î¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¾·Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½»Ï‚;

In this play the fate of Aegisthus forms the climax. Electra has already said that Clytaemnestra shared in the murderous deed (97 ff., 206), and has avowed that she would have wished Orestes to wreak vengeance on her (604). But she does not suggest that she herself or her sister should slay their mother; even the plur. á¼Ï‡Î¸ÏÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ in 979 need not mean more than Aegisthus. Sophocles avoids everything that could qualify our sympathy with Electra; while it suits the different aim of Euripides to make her plan the matricide. See Introduction.

Ï€Î¿á¿– Î³á½°Ï Î¼ÎµÎ½Îµá¿–Ï‚ á¿¥á¾´Î¸Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï‚, Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½·Î½â€™ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 958

Ï€Î¿á¿– â€¦ Î¼ÎµÎ½Îµá¿–Ï‚. For Ï€Î¿á¿– as =Î¼á½³Ï‡ÏÎ¹ Ï„á½·Î½Î¿Ï‚, Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½·Î½Î± Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½, cp. Ar. Lys. 526Ï€Î¿á¿– Î³á½°Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡Ïá¿†Î½ á¼€Î½Î±Î¼Îµá¿–Î½Î±Î¹; It is also possible to join Ï€Î¿á¿– with Î²Î»á½³ÏˆÎ±ÏƒÎ±: â€˜to what quarterâ€”to what hopeâ€” can you look?â€™ But the order of the words is certainly against that.

Î²Î»á½³ÏˆÎ±Ï‚): cp. 888.

960 Ï€Î»Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î¿Ï… ÎºÏ„á¿†ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ·Î¼á½³Î½á¿ƒ, ğŸ—©
Line 960

Line 986

ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï€á½¹Î½ÎµÎ¹ and Ïƒá½»Î³ÎºÎ±Î¼Î½Îµ are here synonymous, though the idea of effort is more prominent in the former, and that of distress in the latter. Instead of repeating a word, the poet often thus uses a synonym; cp. 1308 f. ÏƒÏ„á½³Î³Î±Ï‚ ..Î¿á¼´ÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï‚: O. T. 54á¼„ÏÎ¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚...ÎºÏÎ±Ï„Îµá¿–Ï‚: Ant. 669ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚...Îµá½–: Tr. 457Î´á½³Î´Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ±Ï‚...Ï„Î±ÏÎ²Îµá¿–Ï‚.

Electra has already declared her faith that Agamemnon, in the nether world, is the ally of his children (454 á¼€ÏÏ‰Î³á½¹Î½: cp. 459). Orestes also, as she believes, is now there, working in the same cause. She asks her sister to aid their efforts.

Nauck miserably defaces this passage by adopting the corrupt v. l. á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á¿‡ (i.e. Electra herself), which not only eliminates all thought of Orestes, but also destroys the antithesis marked by á¼Î¼á½³.

Ï€Î±á¿¦ÏƒÎ¿Î½ á¼Îº ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Î½: cp. 231 á¼Îº ÎºÎ±Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï€Î±á½»ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹. For the aor. imper. combined with the pres., cp. Ai. 507Î±á¼´Î´ÎµÏƒÎ±Î¹, Ai. 510Î¿á¼´ÎºÏ„Î¹ÏÎµ.

á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». These words of the Chorus, though neutral in tone (like their words at v. 369), imply that Electra's plan is over-bold, and Chrys. speaks as if sure of their approval; which, indeed, she receives at v. 1015.â€” ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ»á½»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¹: for the omission of the art., cp. 1498: Aesch. The difference between Ï€Îµá½·Î¸Î¿Ï… and Ï€Î¹Î¸Î¿á¿¦ is simply that the pres. implies a mental process (â€˜be persuaded,â€™ â€˜allow the reasoning to weigh with theeâ€™), while the aor. denotes an act (â€˜obey,â€™ â€˜comply,â€™ â€”do the thing recommended). Ï€Îµá½·Î¸Î¿Ï…, as more suggestive of gentle entreaty, seems a little the better here; while Ï€Î¹Î¸Î¿á¿¦ is more fitting in v. 1207. An instance in which metre confirms Ï€Îµá½·Î¸Î¿Ï… is O. C. 520.Our MSS. are precarious guides on such a point: Ï€Îµá½·Î¸Î¿Ï… has the better authority here, but so it has also in 1207 and in Tr. 470, where Ï€Î¹Î¸Î¿á¿¦ is preferable.

1065 Î´Î±Ïá½¸Î½ Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½¹Î½Î·Ï„Î¿Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 1065

á¼€Ï€á½¹Î½Î·Ï„Î¿Î¹=á¼„Ï€Î¿Î½Î¿Î¹, free from trouble or suffering; a form found elsewhere only in the adv. á¼€Ï€Î¿Î½Î·Ï„á½¹Ï„Î±Ï„Î± ( Her. 2. 14). á½¦ Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½·Î± Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Ï†á½±Î¼Î±, ÎºÎ±Ï„á½± Î¼Î¿Î¹ Î²á½¹Î±ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„Ïá½°Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1066

Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½·Î±, preceding Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹, serves to indicate that the dead are meant (cp. 462 Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½ n.): the dat. is ethic, denoting those who perceive the Ï†á½±Î¼Î±. Î¿á½Îºá½³Ï„â€™ á¼Î¾Î¹ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦Ï„Î±Î¹, â€˜is no longer equal isedâ€™; i.e., cannot be resolved into harmony, does not permit unity of feeling, Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿Ï„Î±Ïƒá½·á¿³ Î´Î¹Î±á½·Ï„á¾³, in a friendly homelife; for the dat. seems to be modal rather than instrumental. Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´Îµ Ï†ÎµÏÎ¿Î¼á½³Î½Î±Î½ á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î±: â€˜on account of these,â€”i.e., for observance of them,â€” winning excellent things,â€™ â€˜winning an excellent reward,â€™â€”viz., praise of the noblest kind. Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´Îµ is then a causal gen.: cp. O. T. 48ÏƒÏ‰Ï„á¿†ÏÎ± ÎºÎ»á¿„Î¶ÎµÎ¹ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¸Ï…Î¼á½·Î±Ï‚. Îµá¼´ Î¼Î¿Î¹ Î¾Ï…Î½Îµá½·Î· Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¹ (=Ï†ÎµÏÎ¿Î¼á½³Î½á¿³) | Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ± Ï„á½°Î½ Îµá½”ÏƒÎµÏ€Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼Î³Î½Îµá½·Î±Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½ | á¼”ÏÎ³Ï‰Î½ Ï„Îµ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½, á½§Î½ Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï€Ïá½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ | á½‘Ïˆá½·Ï€Î¿Î´ÎµÏ‚ (â€˜winning the praise of reverent purity,â€™ etc.). But this would be somewhat forced.

I formerly understood:â€”â€˜in respect to these laws, prospering full wellâ€™: á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î± being then an adv., while Ï†ÎµÏÎ¿Î¼á½³Î½Î±Î½ is used as in Thuc. 2. 60Â§ 3 ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚..Ï†ÎµÏá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ á¼‘Î±Ï…Ï„á½¹Î½: 5. 15 Â§ 2 Îµá½– Ï†ÎµÏá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹: 5. 16 Â§ 1 Îµá½– Ï†ÎµÏá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î½ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³á½·Î±Î¹Ï‚. Line 1106

á¼´Î¸), á½¦ Î³á½»Î½Î±Î¹. As á¼´Î¸Î¹ was used in entreaty ( O. T. 46), it is not, in itself, abrupt; but the tone of the direction implies ignorance of Electra's rank, and is thus in keeping with the part of the Phocian Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. Orestes,â€”who thought that he recognised her voice when it was heard from within (v. 80),â€”can, of course, be in no doubt as to her identity. Verse 1125 already indicates this. After v. 1148, at any rate, he would know the fact, if he had been so dull as not to discover it sooner. But he pretends not to know who she is until he hears her name pronounced by the Chorus (1171).

Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, â€˜carryingâ€™ (in the urn), refers simply to the mode of conveyance; ÎºÎ¿Î¼á½·Î¶Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½, â€˜we bring,â€™ expresses the care with which they perform their mission. Line 1115

Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½) Îº.Ï„.Î». Three modes of punctuation are possible; the first is perhaps the best, though the second is also satisfactory. (1) To place no point either after á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½) or after ÏƒÎ±Ï†á½³Ï‚. â€˜There, it seems, I clearly see that sorrow (=the sorrow which I foreboded) in your hands.â€™ ÏƒÎ±Ï†á½²Ï‚ is then equiv. to an adv. with Î´á½³ÏÎºÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹: and the combination of ÏƒÎ±Ï†á½²Ï‚ with Ï€Ïá½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Î½ is like that in Tr. 223Ï„á½±Î´â€™ á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Ï€Ïá¿³ÏÎ± Î´á½µ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ | Î²Î»á½³Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï€á½±ÏÎµÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ³á¿†. (3) To place a point after á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½), and none after ÏƒÎ±Ï†á½³Ï‚. â€˜That is it; I now see clearly,â€™ etc. Cp. Ar. Av. 354Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Â· Ï€Î¿á¿– Ï†á½»Î³Ï‰ Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½Î¿Ï‚; But this colloquialism, though used by Eur. ( Eur. ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á¿†Ï‚ á½ˆÏá½³ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï… Î»Î¿Î¹Ï€á½¹Î½, lit., â€˜remaining from the life of Orestes.â€™

á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½, far away from my hopes, contrary to them: cp. Apoll. Rh. 2. 863 Î¼á½±Î»Î± Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½¸Î½ á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Ï€Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿ Î½á½¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚. So á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î´á½¹Î¾Î·Ï‚, contrary to expectation ( Il. 10. 324, Od. 11. 344): á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î¸Ï…Î¼Î¿á¿¦, unpleasing to one ( Il. 1. 562): Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î·Ï‚, not unwisely ( Tr. 389): and often Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î¿Ï…, not unreasonably: Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÎºÎ±Î¹ÏÎ¿á¿¦: Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î¿á¿¦.

Then Î¿á½Ï‡ á½§Î½Ï€ÎµÏ (if sound) is best explained as standing, by attraction to á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½, for Î¿á½Ï‡ Î±á¼·ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ: and the sense is: â€”â€˜In a manner how contrary to my hopesâ€”not with those hopes wherewith I sent thee forthâ€”have I received thee back.â€™ The notion of contrariety is thus expressed twice over; first by á¼€Ï€á½¹, then by Î¿á½Ï‡. If this is awkward in grammar, yet it has a certain pathetic emphasis.

Other possibilities are the following. (1) Keeping both Î¿á½Ï‡ á½§Î½Ï€ÎµÏ and á¼€Ï€), to take á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ as=â€˜with hopes.â€™ The prep. would then be used as when it denotes a resource: 1378 á¼€Ï†â€™ á½§Î½ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹: Thuc. 1. 91Â§ 7 á¼€Ï€á½¸ á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Ï€á½±Î»Î¿Ï… Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á¿†Ï‚. (Observe that in Soph. Tr. 667á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿†Ï‚ is not really similar; it means, â€˜as the outcome of a fair hope.â€™) The prevailing usage of á¼€Ï€á½¹ condemns this view.

(2) Still keeping Î¿á½Ï‡ á½§Î½Ï€ÎµÏ, to change á¼€Ï€), with Schaefer, to á½‘Ï€). Cp. Eur. Hec. 351á¼Î¸Ïá½³Ï†Î¸Î·Î½ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Î½ á½•Ï€Î¿. This is possible; though á½‘Ï€á½¹, when thus used, commonly denotes an external accompaniment ( Soph. Tr. 419 n.); as, indeed, even in Hec. l. c., the hopes are not merely Polyxena's own, but those of her friends. Further: á½¥Ï‚ Ïƒâ€™ á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´Ï‰Î½â€” á¼€Ï€á½¹ meaning â€˜contrary toâ€™â€”strikes the note of despair more forcibly.

(3) Keeping á¼€Ï€) as=â€˜contrary to,â€™ to alter Î¿á½Ï‡ á½§Î½Ï€ÎµÏ either to Î¿á½Ï‡ á½…Î½Ï€ÎµÏ or to Î¿á½Ï‡ á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ. Each of these occurs in one or more of the later MSS., though probably either by conjecture or by error. Of the two, Î¿á½Ï‡ á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ gives the simplest sense, while Î¿á½Ï‡ á½…Î½Ï€ÎµÏ is perhaps superior in vigour and pathos.

On the whole, I retain the traditional reading, though not without a suspicion that either á¼€Ï€) or á½§Î½Ï€ÎµÏ is unsound.

á½¡Ï‚ á½¤Ï†ÎµÎ»Î¿Î½: cp. Il. 3. 428á½¡Ï‚ á½¤Ï†ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ‚ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î¸â€™ á½€Î»á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. With Homer, á½¡Ï‚ and Î±á¼´Î¸) are alike frequent in this phrase: Attic usage prefers Îµá¼´Î¸) (1021), though á½¡Ï‚ also occurs (as in Ar. Ran. 955, Eur. Ion 286). The simple á½¤Ï†ÎµÎ»Î¿Î½ stands in O.T. 1157, and with Î¼á½µ in Ph. 969, Tr. 998.

The v.l. á½¤Ï†ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ‚ is excluded by ÎºÎ»á½³ÏˆÎ±ÏƒÎ±, since we should then require (á¼Î¼á½²) ÎºÎ»á½³ÏˆÎ±ÏƒÎ±Î½: it would also forestall v. 1134. Electra's self-reproach is that her action, without ultimately saving his life, deprived him of funeral rites at home. She goes on to lament that she herself had not rendered those rites (1138 ff.). That regret might seem inconsistent with her wish in 1131; but it represents a separate thought which rises in her mind as she pictures him perishing among strangers.

Ï„Î¿á¿–Î½Î´Îµ, the fem. form in Attic inscriptions (O.T. 1462 cr. n.).

Line 1152

Ï„á½³Î¸Î½Î·Îºâ€™ á¼Î³á½¼ ÏƒÎ¿á½·: â€˜I am dead in relation to thee.â€™ For Electra, this is another way of saying, â€˜I am dead, so far as any aim or joy in life is concernedâ€™; since the only hopes which made life tolerable to her were centred in her brother. á¼¨Î». Ï„á½· Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ‡ÎµÏ‚ á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚; Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½· Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„â€™ Îµá¼°Ï€á½¼Î½ ÎºÏ…ÏÎµá¿–Ï‚; ğŸ—©
Line 11761176-1226

It is well to observe the delicately gradual process which leads up to the recognition.

(i) 1176â€”1187. She is surprised that her woes should affect the stranger, and he hints that they are his own. (ii) 1188 â€”1198. She is thus led to speak more in detail of her sorrows, and of her despair,â€”caused by her brother's death. (iii) 1199â€”1204. He once more expresses his pity,â€”and this time in words which cause her to ask whether he can be a kinsman. He does not give a direct answer, but inquires whether the Chorus are friendly, and is assured that they are so.

The preparation is now complete: the actual disclosure follows. (i) 1205â€” 1210. He asks her to give him the urn which is in her hands: she entreats that she may be allowed to keep it, and to pay it the last honours. (ii) 1211â€”1217. He tells her that she ought not to mourn for her brother. â€˜Why,â€™ she asks: â€˜if these are his ashes?â€™ â€˜They are not so,â€™ he replies,â€”taking the urn from her hands. (iii) 1218â€”1221. â€˜Where, then,â€™ she asks, â€˜is his grave?â€™ â€˜The living have no grave.â€™ â€˜He lives?â€™ â€˜Yes,â€”as surely as I live.â€™

Ph. 575á½…Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á½ ÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¹Ï‚ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Î¦Î¹Î»Î¿ÎºÏ„á½µÏ„Î·Ï‚, Î¾á½³Î½Îµ.â€”Though joined with Îµá¼¶Î´Î¿Ï‚, ÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Î½ should not be taken as referring to the fame of her beauty; it is equivalent to ÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î½á¿†Ï‚, by the common idiom (785).

á¼¨Î». Ï„á½¹Î´â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½±Î»â€™ á¼€Î¸Î»á½·Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 11781178-1184

Bergk has an ingenious (though, I think, mistaken) theory concerning this passage. Seeing that v. 1180 resembles v. 1184, he suggests that 1180 was an inferior variant for 1184: and, on similar grounds, that 1183 was a feebler substitute for 1179. That is, there were two different texts of this passage. (a) In one of them, the better, verses 1180 and 1183 were absent, and the rest stood in this order, 1178, 1181, 1182, 1179, 1184. (b) In the other, verses 1179 and 1184 were absent, and the rest stood in this order, 1178, 1181, 1182, 1183, 1180. The present text arose from an attempt to harmonise the other two.

We have only to read the dialogue with attention to perceive that this hypothesis of variants is arbitrary. Verse 1183 expresses sympathy in a more definite and emphatic manner than v. 1179: verse 1184 expresses surprise more directly and decidedly than v. 1180. There is a gradual accentuation of the stranger's interest and of Electra's perplexity. This development is the internal proof that our text has not arisen from a dittographia.

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½±Î»): here, as in 1455, the ÎºÎ±á½¶=â€˜andâ€™; sometimes, however, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½±Î»Î±=vel maxime (cp. ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î¿Î»á½», ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î»á½·Î±Î½), as in Xen. Cyr. 6. 1. 36á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚..ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½±Î»Î± Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½á½·Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹.

á½ˆÏ. Î¿á¼´Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î±Î»Î±á½·Î½Î·Ï‚ á¼†ÏÎ± Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 1179

Line 1180

Î¿á½ Î´á½µ Ï€Î¿Ï„), the reading of the scholiast, is clearly better than that which prevails in our MSS., Ï„á½· Î´á½µÏ€Î¿Ï„). It expresses her first feeling of surprise: she can hardly believe that his pity is for her. In 1184, on the other hand, Ï„á½· Î´á½µ Ï€Î¿Ï„) is fitting: she has recognised the fact, and asks the cause. Cp. 1108.

Î´Ï…ÏƒÏ†Î·Î¼Îµá¿–Ï‚: cp. 905 n. The schol. gives the sense rightly, Ï„á½° Î´á½»ÏƒÏ†Î·Î¼Î± Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± á¼‚ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¿á½Îº á¼„Î»Î»á¿³ Ï„Î¹Î½á½¶ á¼ÏÎ¼á½¹Î¶ÎµÎ¹. Line 1183

Î³Î¿Î½Î±á½¶ ÏƒÏ‰Î¼á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». This phrase seems to gain in fulness and force if taken as meaning, â€˜son of the father whom I so loved,â€™ rather than as a mere periphrasis for Ïƒá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î± Ï†á½·Î»Ï„Î±Ï„Î±, â€˜dearest of all men ever bornâ€™: the latter would be weaker than (e.g.) Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½ Ïƒá¿¶Î½..Î´á½·Ï€Ï„Ï…Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ Î³Î¿Î½á½µ ( Eur. (Cp. 206, n. on Î¸Î±Î½á½±Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚.) It is confirmed, however, by the fact that Latin poetry tolerates a corresponding use of corpora: Ovid Her. The plur. certainly cannot be explained by supposing a reference to Pylades also.

Far the most probable account of the text here is that an iambic trimeter was corrupted, first by an accidental transposition of words and then by attempted correction, into the form which appears in most MSS. (cr. n.), á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½ Ï„á½°Î½ á¼ŒÏÏ„ÎµÎ¼Î¹Î½ Ï„á½°Î½ Î±á¼°á½²Î½ á¼€Î´Î¼á½µÏ„Î±Î½. Line 1246

á¼€Î½á½³Ï†ÎµÎ»Î¿Î½ â€¦ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½. Her sorrowâ€”the long and bitter strife with her motherâ€”is one over which, from its nature (Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á¼”Ï†Ï…), no veil can be drawn; it is manifest to all, and fierce, like the sun in a cloudless summer sky. It is a sorrow which can never be done away with, Î¿á½” Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î»á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Î½, because no reconciliation is possible. And it is one of which no time can efface the memory (Î¿á½Î´á½³ Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ Î»Î·Ïƒá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½).

The author of the scholium on 1245 read á¼Î½á½³Î²Î±Î»ÎµÏ‚:â€”á¼Ï€Îµá½·Ï€ÎµÏ á½‘Ï€á½³Î¼Î½Î·ÏƒÎµÎ½ Î±á½Ï„á½´Î½ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î±Î¹Ïá½³ÏƒÎµÏ‰Ï‚, Î´Î¹á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ·Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½ Î´á½»Î¿ ÏƒÏ„á½·Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Ï†Î·Ïƒá½¶Î½ á½…Ï„Î¹ á¼Î½á½³Î²Î±Î»á½³Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¸Î½ á¼€Î½á½³Ï†ÎµÎ»Î¿Î½. This yields a good sense; â€˜thou hast mentionedâ€™ (mentionem iniecisti). Cp. Plat. Rep. 344Î” Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á¼Î¼Î²Î±Î»á½¼Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ á¼Î½ Î½á¿· á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ á¼€Ï€Î¹á½³Î½Î±Î¹. The traditional á¼Ï€á½³Î²Î±Î»ÎµÏ‚ has been explained in two ways. (1) â€˜You have mentioned.â€™ For this sense there is no parallel. (2) â€˜You have laid the burden of the woe upon me,â€™â€”i.e., â€˜brought it to my recollection.â€™ This is perhaps just possible: but it is so artificial as to seem improbable. á½‘Ï€á½³Î²Î±Î»ÎµÏ‚, â€˜you have suggested,â€™ would be an easy correction: cp. 833 á½‘Ï€Î¿á½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚. Ph. 1170Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹á½¸Î½ á¼„Î»Î³Î·Î¼â€™ á½‘Ï€á½³Î¼Î½Î±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚. If, however, it was the original word, the corruption to á¼Ï€á½³Î²Î±Î»ÎµÏ‚ is strange, since the sense would have been clear.

ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î»á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¼Î¿Î½, fitting here, as suggestive of ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î»á½»ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ á¼”Ï‡Î¸ÏÎ±Î½, Ï€á½¹Î»ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î½, Îº.Ï„.Î».

Î»Î·Ïƒá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½: â€˜that never its own burden can forget,â€™ as Whitelaw renders. The ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½ is half-personified here, though not in the preceding clauses; precisely as in Ph. 1167 the Îºá½µÏ (disease) is Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„Ïá½°.. Î²á½¹ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î½, á¼€Î´Î±á½´Ï‚ Î´) | á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¼Ï…Ïá½·Î¿Î½ á¼„Ï‡Î¸Î¿Ï‚ á½ƒ Î¾Ï…Î½Î¿Î¹ÎºÎµá¿– (n.).

The usual explanation is, â€˜that cannot be forgottenâ€™; but Î»á½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ is nowhere passive. There is, indeed, no classical fut. pass. of Î»Î±Î½Î¸á½±Î½Ï‰, for (á¼Ï€Î¹ï¼‰Î»Î·ÏƒÎ¸á½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ occurs only in later Greek (LXX. Ps. ix. 19, etc.). Even Î»ÎµÎ»á½µÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹=â€˜will forget,â€™ Eur. Alc. 198.â€”Î»Î·Ïƒá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ could mean, â€˜that cannot escape noticeâ€™; for, though the act. Î»á½µÏƒÏ‰ is more usual in this sense ( Soph. Tr. 455, Il. 23. 416), the midd. Î»á½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ is so used by Hippocrates (2. 170), Arist. (Pr. Anal. 2. 19), Lucian, etc. But here, especially after á¼€Î½á½³Ï†ÎµÎ»Î¿Î½, such a sense would evidently be too weak.

Î¿á½Î´á½³ Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ Î»Î·Ïƒá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ á¼Î¼á½³Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½
1250 Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ á¼”Ï†Ï… ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½.
á½ˆÏ. á¼”Î¾Î¿Î¹Î´Î±, Ï€Î±á¿–, Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™Â· á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½…Ï„Î±Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½·Î± ğŸ—©
Line 1251

á¼”Î¾Î¿Î¹Î´Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„): â€˜these things also,â€™ i.e., the sufferings to which she has just alluded. The change of ÎºÎ±á½¶ to Ï€Î±á¿– (rightly made in Ph. 79) is needless here.

Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½·Î± may be freely rendered â€˜occasionâ€™; it seems to be a purposely vague word, intended to suggest â€˜the presenceâ€™ of the murderers; a dark hint of the coming vengeance. When their presence admonishes (Ï†Ïá½±Î¶á¿ƒ),â€”gives the signal for action,â€”then will be the time to recall their crimes; which are indicated, with a similar reserve, by á¼”ÏÎ³Ï‰Î½ Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´Îµ.

The scholia attest Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½·Î± as the traditional reading, and suggest two explanations. (1) á½…Ï„Î±Î½ á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„Ïá½³Ï€á¿ƒ á½ ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿‡: i.e., Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½·Î±=Ï„á½° Ï€Î±Ïá½¹Î½Ï„Î±, the circumstances of the moment. Cp. cum res ipsa feret. (2) á½Ï€á½¹Ï„Î±Î½ á¼¡ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïƒá½·Î± Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¾– ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½ ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„á½µÎ´ÎµÎ¹Î¿Ï‚. Here Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ is evidently neuter, and the meaning is, â€˜when these topics come before us,â€™â€”when it is the fitting time to discuss them. Neither view is satisfactory.

The v.l. Ï€Î±ÏÏÎ·Ïƒá½·Î±, doubtless a conjecture, would enfeeble the passage, and would further require us to alter Ï†Ïá½±Î¶á¿ƒ.

á½ Ï€á¾¶Ï‚ â€¦ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚, â€˜all timeâ€™ to come: cp. Line 1281

á½¦ Ï†á½·Î»Î±Î¹. It seems fitting that, towards the close of these lyrics, Electra should address some words to the sympathetic Chorus,â€”as she did before, just after the discovery (1227); though at v. 1285 she again speaks to Orestes. The emendation á½¦ Ï†á½·Î»), á½…Ï„) (Wunder), like others designed to alter Ï†á½·Î»Î±Î¹, is hardly probable.

Î±á½Î´á½±Î½ is unquestionably the living voice of Orestes, which â€˜she could never have hoped to hear,â€™ after the apparent proofs of his death. Cp. 1225 á½¦ Ï†Î¸á½³Î³á½, á¼€Ï†á½·ÎºÎ¿Ï…: and with Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼¤Î»Ï€Î¹Ï‚), cp. 1263 á¼€á½³Î»Ï€Ï„Ï‰Ï‚: 832 f. Îµá¼° Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï†Î±Î½ÎµÏá¿¶Ï‚ Î¿á¼°Ï‡Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½ | Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼ˆá¿“Î´Î±Î½ á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î´â€™ á½‘Ï€Î¿á½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚: and 858 f. The first and best scholium on 1281 recognises that Î±á½Î´á½±Î½ denotes a source of joy, not of grief, to her (ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á½°Ï á¼¡ á¼¡Î´Î¿Î½á½´ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎµÏ„Ïá½³Ï€ÎµÏ„Î¿ Î±á½Ï„á½´Î½ Î²Î¿á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹), though wrongly explaining the word as Ï†á½µÎ¼Î·Î½ Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†Î¿á¿¦ (news of his safety). If Î±á½Î´á½±Î½ meant the report of his death, the words á¼ƒÎ½ á¼Î³á½¼ Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼¤Î»Ï€Î¹Ï‚) would lose all force.

1283 f. There can be no doubt that something has been lost before á¼”ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î½. Arndt supplies Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½, which might easily have been omitted, either through its likeness to Î±á½Î´á½±Î½ just before it, or through the Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ above it. á½ÏÎ¼á½°Î½, for the traditional á½€ÏÎ³á½°Î½, is due to Blomfield (Mus. Crit. 1. 214).

á½€ÏÎ³á½µ in Sophocles means either (1) â€˜anger,â€™ or (2) â€˜dispositionâ€™: Ant. 875Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î³Î½Ï‰Ï„Î¿Ï‚..á½€ÏÎ³á½±: ib. 355 á¼€ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î½Î¿Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á½€ÏÎ³á½±Ï‚: Ai. 639ÏƒÏ…Î½Ï„Ïá½¹Ï†Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á½€ÏÎ³Î±á¿–Ï‚. Neither sense can be fitted into any probable interpretation. Some have supposed the meaning to be that Electra â€˜restrained her anger in silence,â€™ when Clyt. was exulting in the death of Orestes; but, in fact, her anger found a voice (see 792). Others understand that she â€˜restrained her emotionâ€™ (of grief), on hearing the sad news; but she did not do so (see 823â€”870): nor could á½€ÏÎ³á½°Î½ mean â€˜emotionâ€™ in that sense.

On the other hand á½€ÏÎ³á½µ and á½ÏÎ¼á½µ were easily confused in MSS. Thus in Tr. 720, where á½ÏÎ¼á¿‡ is right, Î³ has been written over Î¼ in L, and á½€ÏÎ³á¿‡ is actually the reading of A, and of the Aldine. Cp. also O. T. 337.

The context is the best guide to the sense which should be restored. Through out these lyrics, Orestes has been endeavouring to repress Electra's cries, lest she should be overheard (1236, 1238, 1251 f., 1257, 1259, 1271 f.). The corrupt words probably referred to this. á½ÏÎ¼á½°Î½ is the â€˜impulseâ€™ or â€˜emotionâ€™ which compelled her to utter her new joy. She turns to these sympathetic women, and excuses her incaution by her happiness.

Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î½ is the potential indicative: see Goodwin, Moods and Tenses, new ed., Â§ 244. Cp. Dem. or. 37 Â§ 57 Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ á¼‚Î½...á¼Î³á½½ Ï„á½· ÏƒÎµ á¼ Î´á½·ÎºÎ·ÏƒÎ±; (â€˜how could I possibly have wronged thee?â€™). á¼„Î½Î±Ï…Î´Î¿Î½, proleptic: Aesch. Ag. 1247Îµá½”Ï†Î·Î¼Î¿Î½... ÎºÎ¿á½·Î¼Î·ÏƒÎ¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±.

Other interpretations and conjectures will be found in the Appendix.

á¼¨Î». á½¦ Ï†á½·Î»Î±Î¹, á¼”ÎºÎ»Ï…Î¿Î½ á¼ƒÎ½ á¼Î³á½¼ Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼¤Î»Ï€Î¹Ïƒâ€™ Î±á½Î´á½±Î½,

Line 1285

Ï„á½±Î»Î±Î¹Î½Î± is a comment on her own joyous emotion, precisely as in 902 ÎºÎµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ Ï„á½±Î»Î±Î¹Î½â€™ á½¡Ï‚ Îµá¼¶Î´Î¿Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î».

Ï†Î¹Î»Ï„á½±Ï„Î±Î½ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¿ÏˆÎ¹Î½,

á½ˆÏ. Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÏƒÏƒÎµá½»Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½ á¼„Ï†ÎµÏ‚, ğŸ—©
Line 12881288-1383

The first part of the third á¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïƒá½¹Î´Î¹Î¿Î½ began, at 1098, with the entrance of Orestes. Now, after the Î¼á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½á¿†Ï‚ (1232â€”1287), comes the second part, going down to the point at which the avengers pass into the house, followed by Electra.

Ï„á½° â€¦ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ‚. Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½: cp. Ph. 24Ï„á¼€Ï€á½·Î»Î¿Î¹Ï€Î± Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½ (n.).

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ Î¼á½µÏ„Î·Ï á½¡Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Îºá½´ Î´á½·Î´Î±ÏƒÎºá½³ Î¼Îµ, ğŸ—©
Line 1289

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½µÏ„Îµ Î¼á½µÏ„Î·Ï Îº.Ï„.Î». These verses plainly intimate the poet's opinion that it would be a fault in art to retard the action at this point by a long narrative. A similar criticism is implied in O. C. 1115 f., ÎºÎ±á½· Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½° Ï€ÏÎ±Ï‡Î¸á½³Î½Ï„â€™ Îµá¼´Ï€Î±Î¸â€™ á½¡Ï‚ Î²Ïá½±Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„), á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ | Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Î·Î»Î¹ÎºÎ±á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ ÏƒÎ¼Î¹ÎºÏá½¸Ï‚ á¼Î¾Î±ÏÎºÎµá¿– Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚ (n.).

Conington (Journ. of Philology, I. p. 156) supposes an allusion to Eur. El. 300â€”338, where Electra, speaking to the disguised Orestes, mentions her own sufferings, her mother's splendours, and the insolence of Aegisthus. But such an allusion seems improbable: that speech is not long; it comes in with dramatic fitness; nor does it refer to the wasteful profusion of Aegisthus, which is the main point here. A later speech of Electra's in the same play (Eur. El. 907â€”951) would in some respects suit the words here better; but that is spoken over the corpse of Aegisthus, and could scarcely be regarded as delaying the action.

Another theory, that Sophocles alludes to the earlier part of the Choephori, is certainly mistaken. Possibly he had no particular work in view, but was merely glancing at a tendency which he had noticed in contemporary drama.

Line 1290

á½‘Ï€Î·ÏÎµÏ„Î¿á½·Î·Î½ is a certain correction of the MS. á½‘Ï€Î·ÏÎµÏ„Î¿á½·Î¼Î·Î½. The midd. is not found in classical writers, though it was frequent later. Ï‡Î±Ïá¾· is right. The objection to the MS. Ï‡Î±Ïá¾¶Ï‚, which Hermann and Paley keep, is the sense. She means that her tears of joy will be mistaken by Clyt. for tears of sorrow. 1320 Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Î´Ï…Î¿á¿–Î½ á¼¥Î¼Î±ÏÏ„Î¿Î½Â· á¼¢ Î³á½°Ï á¼‚Î½ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 1320

Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Î´Ï…Î¿á¿–Î½ á¼¥Î¼Î±ÏÏ„Î¿Î½, i.e., would have secured one of the two things. Classical Greek idiom preferred this negative form to a positive (such as Î´Ï…Î¿á¿–Î½ Î¸Î±Ï„á½³ÏÎ¿Ï… á¼‚Î½ á¼”Ï„Ï…Ï‡Î¿Î½). The modes of stating the dilemma vary; thus we find: (1) á¼¢ Î³á½°Ï..á¼¢, as here; Andoc. or. 1 Â§ 4 Î´Ï…Î¿á¿–Î½.. Î¿á½Îº á¼¦Î½ Î±á½Ï„á¿· á¼Î¼Î±ÏÏ„Îµá¿–Î½Â· á¼¢ Î³á½°Ï..Î¼Î·Î½á¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î¹.. á¼¢ á¼€Ï€Î¿ÎºÏ„Îµá¿–Î½Î±Î¹: so Dem. or. 19 Â§ 151, etc. (2) á¼¢..á¼¢, as Thuc. 1. 33Â§ 3 Î¼Î·Î´á½² Î´Ï…Î¿á¿–Î½ Ï†Î¸á½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹ á¼Î¼á½±ÏÏ„Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹Î½ (not fail to be beforehand with us in one of two things), á¼¢ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶ÏƒÎ±Î¹..á¼¢ Î²ÎµÎ²Î±Î¹á½½ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ n. (3) Îµá¼° Î¼á½²Î½ Î³á½°Ï..Îµá¼° Î´á½², as Isocr. or. 11 Â§ 43.â€”Remark that the modification of this phrase used by Eur. Or. 1151, á¼‘Î½á½¸Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½ ÏƒÏ†Î±Î»á½³Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼•Î¾Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ ÎºÎ»á½³Î¿Ï‚, | ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ Î¸Î±Î½á½¹Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ á¼¢ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ ÏƒÎµÏƒÏ‰ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹,â€”where Î´Ï…Î¿á¿–Î½ is merely a bad conjecture,â€”is due to the fact that the principal verb, á¼•Î¾Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½, is positive.

Line 13391339-1345

It has been held that these verses, or at least 1340â€”1344, are spurious (cr. n.). Certainly Orestes has already heard from Electra that Clytaemnestra exults in the news of his death (1153â€”1156). Still, it is natural that he should make some reference (as he does in 1341) to his emissary's performance of the task. Not less natural is the question in 1343, since the old man, who entered the house at v. 803, is the only person who can tell whether the feeling described by Electra still exists.

Line 1361

Ï€Î±Ï„á½³ÏÎ±. This is the only tragic trimeter in which the third foot is formed by a single word of three short syllables. When the third foot is a tribrach there is usu. a caesura both in the third and in the fourth foot (as O. T. 248ÎºÎ±Îºá½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Ï‚ Î½Î¹Î½ á¼„Î¼Î¿ÏÎ¿Î½ á¼ÎºÏ„Ïá¿–ÏˆÎ±Î¹ Î²á½·Î¿Î½: cp. Eur. Tro. 497): or at least in the third foot (as Soph. Ant. 31). But it should be observed that the pause after Ï‡Î±á¿–á¿¤, á½¦ Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ makes a vital difference. The movement of the verse begins afresh at Ï€Î±Ï„á½³ÏÎ±, and the effect of that word to the ear is like that of a tribrach in the first, rather than in the third, place of a trimeter. Hence we may defend the text here, and yet concede that no tragic poet could have written such a verse without the pause (e.g. á¼¦Î»Î¸â€™ á¼„ÏƒÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ï„á½³ÏÎ± Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¾¶Î½ Î´Î¿Îºá¿¶Î½).

1380 I read Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„Ï‰, as metre requires, not Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï€á½·Ï„Î½Ï‰. The first syllable of Ï€á½·Ï„Î½Ï‰ is never long. Thus, where Î¹^ is needed, Aesch. á¼¨Î». á½¦ Ï†á½·Î»Ï„Î±Ï„Î±Î¹ Î³Ï…Î½Î±á¿–ÎºÎµÏ‚, á¼…Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚ Î±á½Ï„á½·ÎºÎ± ğŸ—©
Line 13981398-1441

A kommos. It falls into two principal parts. (1) 1398â€”1421; the death of Clytaemnestra. (2) 1422â€” 1441; Orestes and Pylades re-enter; Aegisthus approaches; and they prepare to receive him.

The general structure of this kommos is clearly strophic; but critics differ on details. The simplest view is that of Dindorf and others, that vv. 1398â€”1421 form a single strophe,=antistr. 1422â€” 1441. The lyric verses 1407, 1413â€”4, and 1419â€”1421, correspond respectively with 1428, 1433â€”4, and 1439â€”1441: for these, see Metrical Analysis. It is usually held, with Hermann, that the correspondence of the iambic trimeters also must be exact. This makes it necessary to assume a gap in our text after v. 1427 (n.), and a second after 1429 (n.), besides the defect in 1432. See Appendix.

Electra hastens out of the house. She performs the part of an <*>Î¾á½±Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î¿Ï‚, so far as to describe the situation at this moment in the house: then Clytaemnestra's cry is heard, like that of the dying king in Aesch. Ag. 1343 ff. In the Orestes (408 B.C.) Electra has a similar part, perhaps suggested by this. Helen's cry is heard within, and Electra says to the Chorus (1297), á¼ ÎºÎ¿á½»ÏƒÎ±Î¸); á¼…Î½Î´ÏÎµÏ‚ Ï‡Îµá¿–Ïâ€™ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼Î½ Ï†á½¹Î½á¿³.

Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„Î¿á½”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½Â· á¼€Î»Î»á½° Ïƒá¿–Î³Î± Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¼ÎµÎ½Îµ. ğŸ—©
Line 1399

á½ Î³ÎµÎ½Î½á½µÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ï„á½µÏ: cp. 261: Tr. 311á½ Ï†Î¹Ï„á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ï„á½µÏ: O. T. 793Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï†Ï…Ï„Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚.

1413 f. The traditional reading Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ is vindicated, and all difficulty is removed, by the slight change of ÏƒÎµ to ÏƒÎ¿Î¹. The Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ± ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î± is the fate which has afflicted the house day by day. In the only other place where ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±Î¼á½³ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ occurs ( Soph. Ph. 229), it has this sense, â€˜dailyâ€™; nor is any other, indeed, tenable. (Cp. 259 ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï.) This fate is now being extinguished (Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ï¼‰ by the righteous act of vengeance, which, according to the poet's view in this play, closes the misfortunes of the race (cp. 1510 Ï„á¿‡ Î½á¿¦Î½ á½ÏÎ¼á¿‡ Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ‰Î¸á½³Î½). For Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ said of an evil which wanes or dies out, cp. fr. 718 (á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚)..á¼€Î½Î¸Îµá¿– Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Ï€á½±Î»Î¹Î½.

Others explain as follows. (1) Keeping both ÏƒÎµ and Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹: â€˜fate is destroying thee this day.â€™ But the alleged evidence for a transitive use of Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ is very small and doubtful: see Appendix. (2) Keeping ÏƒÎµ, but reading Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½: â€˜now it is the doom of this day that thou shouldst fade.â€™ Both these versions force an impossible sense on ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î±. That explanation of it was a mere makeshift of the scholiast; á½¦ Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¿á¼´ÎºÎ¿Ï… Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï…, ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ï„Î±á½»Ï„Î·Î½ ÏƒÎµ Ï„á½´Î½ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Î½ á¼¡ ÎœÎ¿á¿–ÏÎ± Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï†Î¸Î¿Ïá½°Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î»á½±Ï„Ï„Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼„Î³ÎµÎ¹.

Nor is the objection to these interpretations merely verbal. They represent the Chorus as deploring that doom of the race which entails yet another deed of bloodshed. But, as Whitelaw well observes, this commits Sophocles to the Aeschylean view of the vengeance â€˜as a new crime in the series of crimesâ€™ (Translation, p. 437). The Chorus are in the fullest sympathy with the avengers. They regard the slaying of Clytaemnestra not as a new calamity, but as a welcome retribution: cp. 1434 Ï„á½° Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ Îµá½– Î¸á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹, and 1508 ff. The words á½¦ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚, á½¦ Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá½° express the feeling of these Ï€Î¿Î»á½·Ï„Î¹Î´ÎµÏ‚ (1227) that the cause of the house is that of the city. They hail the approaching deliverance of Mycenae from the tyrants. The change of á½¦ Ï€á½¹Î»Î¹Ï‚, á½¦ Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá½° into á½¦ Î á½³Î»Î¿Ï€Î¿Ï‚ Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá½° (cr. n.) is equally rash and infelicitous.

Îµá¼° Î³á½°Ï Î‘á¼°Î³á½·ÏƒÎ¸á¿³ Î³â€™ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ (adv.). Ïˆá½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½, Erfurdt's correction of Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½, deserves the favour which it has found with almost all editors from Hermann onwards. After v. 1427 Erfurdt and others suppose the loss of three verses answering to vv. 1404â€”1406 (Î±á¼°Î±á¿–...Ï†á½·Î»Î±Î¹): see note in Appendix on 1398. The context itself, however, does not indicate any lacuna. In a calmer scene, doubtless, we might have looked for some comment from Electra on the announcement that Clytaemnestra is dead. But this is a passage full of excitement and hurrying action. Î²á¾¶Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹Î¸á½»ÏÏ‰Î½, â€˜make for the vestibule.â€™ If the words are sound, ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±, lit. â€˜down upon,â€™ denotes the point on which the rapid movement is directed. The word á¼€Î½Ï„á½·Î¸Ï…ÏÎ¿Î½ is known only from the following passages. The ground for giving the words á¾— Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚ to Electra, rather than to Orestes (cr. n.), is not merely that her share in this verse then becomes the same as in v. 1415. That ground would be inconclusive (cp. 1431 n.). The better reasons are these: (1) the simple Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î¼ÎµÎ½ is thus far more forcible. Line 1435Line 1435

á¾— Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚, lit., hasten â€˜on the path that thou hast in view,â€™â€”i.e., to the execution of the plan within the house. Cp. Ai. 868Ï€á¾· Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½Îº á¼”Î²Î±Î½ á¼Î³á½½;

The ground for giving the words á¾— Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚ to Electra, rather than to Orestes (cr. n.), is not merely that her share in this verse then becomes the same as in v. 1415. That ground would be inconclusive (cp. 1431 n.). The better reasons are these: (1) the simple Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î¼ÎµÎ½ is thus far more forcible. (2) á¾— Î½Î¿Îµá¿–Ï‚, if said by Orestes, would be a feeble reference to the wish of the Chorus; as said by Electra, it is a natural comment on Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î¼ÎµÎ½.

Line 14371437-1441

Line 1448

ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚, which can denote either good fortune (1230) or evil, suits the purposed ambiguity. For the ear of Aegisthus, her reply means: â€˜Of course I know; else I should be a stranger to the fortune of my nearest kinswoman,â€™â€” viz., her mother. She leaves him to decide whether she means that Clytaemnestra is afflicted or rejoiced by the news. And meanwhile á¼¡ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½° Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï†Î¹Î»Ï„á½±Ï„Î·Ï‚ has a further meaningâ€”Clytaemnestra<*>s deathâ€”which he cannot yet surmise.

Possibly this is the only ambiguity intended. Line 1462

ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î¹Î±, poet. plur.; so Aesch. Ag. 237Ï‡Î±Î»Î¹Î½á¿¶Î½. Cp. Compar. Pericl. et Fabii 1 ÏƒÏ€Î±ÏÎ³á¿¶Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï„á¿· Î´á½µÎ¼á¿³ Ï‡Î±Î»Î¹Î½á½¸Î½ á¼Î¼Î²Î±Î»Îµá¿–Î½ á½•Î²ÏÎµÏ‰Ï‚.

Line 1464

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´á½´ Îº.Ï„.Î».: lit. â€˜already my part is being performed.â€™ For Ï„á¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦ cp. O. C. 1682Ï„á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Î²ÏÎ±Î´á½»Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. She refers ostensibly to what he has just said: â€˜I, at least, am already resolved to be loyal and docile.â€™ Her secret meaning is, â€˜My part in the plan of vengeance is being accomplished.â€™ She is luring him to his fate: cp. 1438 Ï„á¼€Î½Î¸á½±Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î¼á½³Î»Î¿Î¹Ï„â€™ á¼‘Î¼Î¿á½·.

Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹ is pres. There is no certain instance in Attic of Ï„ÎµÎ»Î¿á¿¦Î¼Î±Î¹ as fut. pass. ( Ph. 1381 n.).

Ï„á¿· â€¦ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³: for the art., cp. 1013.

ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÏÎµá½·ÏƒÏƒÎ¿ÏƒÎ¹Î½, to agree with them, to live in concord with them. Cp. Eur. Med. 13Î±á½Ï„á½µ Ï„Îµ Ï€á¼€Î½Ï„Î± ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Ï…Ïƒâ€™ á¼¸á½±ÏƒÎ¿Î½Î¹. Ar. Lys. 166 á¼€Î½á½µÏ, á¼á½°Î½ Î¼á½´ Ï„á¿‡ Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá½¶ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†á½³Ïá¿ƒ. This sense comes from that of â€˜sharing a burdenâ€™ (946), so that it resembles our phrase, â€˜pull together.â€™ Here it suits her inner meaning,â€”that she is working with those who now are the stronger (i.e., the avengers).

As Electra utters these words, the central doors are opened, and the eccyclema is pushed forward. This was a small and low stage. A corpse is seen upon it, the face and outlines concealed by a covering. Near it stand Orestes and Pyladesâ€”the â€˜Phociansâ€™ whom Aegisthus seeks. The eccyclema remains displayed to the end, and at v. 1507 Orestes and Pylades go out behind it. So in the Antigone the eccyclema is in view from 1293 to the close, and at 1347 Creon is led off behind it.

The corpse here is an effigy, like that of Haemon in Ant. 1261 ff. The deuteragonist, who had played Clytaemnestra, is now playing Orestes.

1465 Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î½, á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÏÎµá½·ÏƒÏƒÎ¿ÏƒÎ¹Î½.
Î‘á¼´. á½¦ Î–Îµá¿¦, Î´á½³Î´Î¿ÏÎºÎ± Ï†á½±ÏƒÎ¼â€™ á¼„Î½ÎµÏ… Ï†Î¸á½¹Î½Î¿Ï… Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½ ğŸ—©
Line 1466

Î´á½³Î´Î¿ÏÎºÎ± Ï†á½±ÏƒÎ¼) Îº.Ï„.Î».: â€˜I behold that which has not fallen without the jealousy of the gods.â€™ Aegisthus is not openly exulting here; he veils his joy in specious language, for he is in public, and speaks before hearers whom he distrusts. He affects to think that the gods have struck down his enemy. The meaning implied by Ï†Î¸á½¹Î½Î¿Ï… is that Orestes had incurred the divine displeasure by unnatural threats against his mother and his step-father (779 Î´Îµá½·Î½â€™ á¼Ï€Î·Ï€Îµá½·Î»ÎµÎ¹ Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½).

The invocation, á½¦ Î–Îµá¿¦, at once indicates the sense of Ï†Î¸á½¹Î½Î¿Ï… as = the divine jealousy. For that sense, see on Ph. 776Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï†Î¸á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Î´á½² Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎºÏ…ÏƒÎ¿Î½.â€”The word Ï†á½±ÏƒÎ¼Î± is chosen on account of Î´á½³Î´Î¿ÏÎºÎ±, in place of a word like Ïƒá¿¶Î¼Î±, or Ï€Ï„á¿¶Î¼Î±, adapted to Ï€ÎµÏ€Ï„Ï‰Îºá½¹Ï‚. In Tr. 693, on the other hand, Î´á½³ÏÎºÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï†á½±Ï„Î¹Î½ | á¼„Ï†ÏÎ±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½, the subst. is adapted to the adj.â€” For other views, see Appendix.

á¼”Ï€ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹: cp. Aesch. Eum. 542Ï€Î¿Î¹Î½á½° Î³á½°Ï á¼Ï€á½³ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹: Xen. Cyr. 6. 2. 33á¼”Ï€ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹ Î³á½±Ï Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î½Î·.

Î½á½³Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, the divine resentment; O. C. 1753Ï€ÎµÎ½Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ Î¿á½ Ï‡Ïá½µÂ· Î½á½³Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ Î³á½±Ï. Nemesis is not here so definitely a person as above in 792.

Ï„á½¸ ÏƒÏ…Î³Î³ÎµÎ½á½³Ï‚: the neuter gender suits the intended ambiguity.

á¼€ÏÎºÏ…ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î¿Î¹Ï‚. The á¼„ÏÎºÏ…Ï‚ (cassisï¼‰ was a hunting tunnel-net, ending in a pouch (ÎºÎµÎºÏá½»Ï†Î±Î»Î¿Ï‚, Cyneg. 6 Â§ 7). It was meant to receive the game when driven to the extremity of the enclosed ground. á¼€ÏÎºá½»ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î± (á¼„ÏÎºÏ…Ï‚, á¼µÏƒÏ„Î·Î¼Î¹) meant properly such nets when set up; and á¼€ÏÎºÏ…ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î½, or á¼€ÏÎºÏ…ÏƒÏ„Î±Ïƒá½·Î±, is the enclosure formed by them ( Cyneg. 6 Â§ 6). When used figuratively, as here, the word suggests, not merely the capture of the victim, but also the act of decoying or driving him into the toils. It is thus more expressive than Î´á½·ÎºÏ„Ï…Î¿Î½ (the general word for â€˜netâ€™), á¼€Î¼Ï†á½·Î²Î»Î·ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Î½ (â€˜castingnetâ€™), or Î³á½±Î³Î³Î±Î¼Î¿Î½ (a circular fishing-net), â€”which are also used metaphorically ( Aesch. Ag. 358, Aesch. Ag. 1382, Aesch. Ag. 361). Cp. Aesch. Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½ is a partitive gen., on which Î¸Î½á¿„ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î½ á½ Î¼á½³Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ depends (cp. Thuc. 4. 102Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½, etc.); though the sense is not affected in a translation if it be rendered as a gen. absol.

Shelley, The Cenci, act 5, sc. 4: â€˜Be constant to the love | Thou bearest us; and to the faith that I, | Though wrapt in a strange cloud of crime and shame, | Lived ever holy and unstained.â€™

Î¸Î½á¿„ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î½: for the pres. inf. with Î¼á½³Î»Î»Ï‰, cp. n. on O. T. 967.

Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï…, the time implied in Î¼Î·Îºá½»Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½.

Many recent critics follow Dindorf in suspecting or bracketing these two verses. Two things should be clearly recognised at the outset. First, that no suspicion is warranted by the fact that the scribe of L accidentally omitted these verses from the text,â€”as he also omitted several lines elsewhere which are undoubtedly genuine. Secondly, that in the language of these verses there is nothing to which exception can fairly be taken. If they are rejected, it must be on the ground that the thought which they express is inappropriate. But is it so? Aegisthus has appealed to mercy, asking for a brief respite. Electra fears that her brother may relent. What gain, she asks, would such a respite be, even to the doomed wretch himself? And her own feeling requires his instant death. It should be noted also that such a pair of verses, containing a general sentiment in an interrogative form, is Sophoclean; cp. Ai. 475Ï„á½· Î³á½°Ï Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ± Ï„á½³ÏÏ€ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ | Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± Îºá¼€Î½Î±Î¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î³Îµ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½; also Ant. 463 f.

Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½, á¼€Î´ÎµÎ»Ï†á½³, Î¼Î·Î´á½² Î¼Î·Îºá½»Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…Ï‚.
1485 Ï„á½· Î³á½°Ï Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼‚Î½ Ïƒá½ºÎ½ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÎ¼Î¹Î³Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1485Line 1485

Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½ is a partitive gen., on which Î¸Î½á¿„ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î½ á½ Î¼á½³Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ depends (cp. Thuc. 4. 102Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½, etc.); though the sense is not affected in a translation if it be rendered as a gen. absol.

Ïƒá½ºÎ½ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÎ¼Î¹Î³Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½, â€˜involved in miseries,â€™ implying here, â€˜crimes, and their consequences.â€™ Cp. Od. 20. 203ï¼ˆá¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚) Î¼Î¹ÏƒÎ³á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Ï„Î·Ï„Î¹. For Ïƒá½ºÎ½ (which need not be taken as a case of tmesis), cp. Pind. N. 3. 77Î¼ÎµÎ¼Î¹Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î½ Î¼á½³Î»Î¹ Î»ÎµÏ…Îºá¿· | Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Î³á½±Î»Î±ÎºÏ„Î¹. So Pind. I. 3. 3á¼„Î¾Î¹Î¿Ï‚ Îµá½Î»Î¿Î³á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼€ÏƒÏ„á¿¶Î½ Î¼ÎµÎ¼á¿–Ï‡Î¸Î±Î¹. The converse phrase (like Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½ Î¼Î¿Î¹ relatively to Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿·, Pind. I. 240 n.) occurs in Her. 7. 203Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹ Î´á½² Î¸Î½Î·Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¿á½Î´á½³Î½Î± Î¿á½Î´á½² á¼”ÏƒÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿· ÎºÎ±Îºá½¸Î½ á½²Î¾ á¼€ÏÏ‡á¿†Ï‚ Î³Î¹Î½Î¿Î¼á½³Î½á¿³ Î¿á½ ÏƒÏ…Î½ÎµÎ¼á½·Ï‡Î¸Î·. We may also compare Soph. Ant. 1311Î´ÎµÎ¹Î»Î±á½·á¾³ Î´á½² ÏƒÏ…Î³Îºá½³ÏÎ±Î¼Î±Î¹ Î´á½»á¾³ (â€˜steeped in itâ€™): Plut. 853 Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰ Ï€Î¿Î»Ï…Ï†á½¹Ïá¿³ ÏƒÏ…Î³Îºá½³ÎºÏÎ±Î¼Î±Î¹ Î´Î±á½·Î¼Î¿Î½Î¹. Shelley, The Cenci, act 5, sc. 4: â€˜Be constant to the love | Thou bearest us; and to the faith that I, | Though wrapt in a strange cloud of crime and shame, | Lived ever holy and unstained.â€™

Î¸Î½á¿„ÏƒÎºÎµÎ¹Î½: for the pres. inf. with Î¼á½³Î»Î»Ï‰, cp. n. on O. T. 967.

Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï…, the time implied in Î¼Î·Îºá½»Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½.

Many recent critics follow Dindorf in suspecting or bracketing these two verses. Two things should be clearly recognised at the outset. First, that no suspicion is warranted by the fact that the scribe of L accidentally omitted these verses from the text,â€”as he also omitted several lines elsewhere which are undoubtedly genuine. Secondly, that in the language of these verses there is nothing to which exception can fairly be taken. If they are rejected, it must be on the ground that the thought which they express is inappropriate. But is it so? Aegisthus has appealed to mercy, asking for a brief respite. Electra fears that her brother may relent. What gain, she asks, would such a respite be, even to the doomed wretch himself? And her own feeling requires his instant death. It should be noted also that such a pair of verses, containing a general sentiment in an interrogative form, is Sophoclean; cp. Ai. 475Ï„á½· Î³á½°Ï Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ± Ï„á½³ÏÏ€ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ | Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± Îºá¼€Î½Î±Î¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î³Îµ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½; also Ant. 463 f.

Ï€Ïá½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ â€¦ ÎºÏ„Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½. In its primary and usual sense, Ï€Ïá½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚ denotes what is ready in the hand (1116). Aegisthus means: â€˜Must this house witness, not only those sorrows of our family which exist already, but those others which are to come, if I am slain?â€™ He speaks of his impending doom as if it were due, not to his own crimes, but to the working of the hereditary á¼€Ïá½±, and implies that it will be followed by other deeds of bloodshed. In saying Î ÎµÎ»Î¿Ï€Î¹Î´á¿¶Î½, he appeals, as a last hope, to family sympathies. Thyestidae, like himself, and Atreidae, like Orestes, are alike â€˜children of Pelops.â€™ According to the legend, the calamities of the house were closed by the righteous vengeance of Orestes, whom Athena's judgment vindicated from the Furies.

1502 The double change of person within the verse ( Or.â€”Aeg.â€” Or.) is rare. As G. Wolff observes, there is no instance of it in Aesch. ; in Soph. the only other examples occur in the two latest plays, Soph. O. C. 832, Soph. Ph. 810, Soph. Ph. 814, Soph. Ph. 816, at moments of high excitement. A triple change within the verse occurs only once, in Soph. Ph. 753.This is another point which bcars on the date of the Electra: cp. 1160 n.

á¼•ÏÏ†). The word is always so written here, as if Orestes could foresee that Aegisthus would utter an aspirated word. Similar instances occur elsewhere: see Appendix. In the theatre, we must suppose, the actor said á¼•ÏÏ€Îµ at full length: and possibly the poet so wrote it.

The imperf. Ï‡Ïá¿†Î½, with Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹, implies that, though it ought to be so, it is not. The sense is, in substance, what might be expressed by a conditional sentence, á¼¥Î´Îµ Î´á½·ÎºÎ· á¼¦Î½ á¼‚Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½, Îµá¼° Ï„á½¸ Îµá¼°Îºá½¸Ï‚ á¼”Ï€Î±Î¸Î¿Î½.

Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚, immediately after the crime in each case; Aegisthus has enjoyed too long an impunity. Cp. 13 f.n.

Î¸á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹ is better here than Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î¹, since it suggests more clearly the reference to the actual case of Aegisthus. The optative is, however, also tenable. It would mark the generality of the statement, â€˜any one who should wishâ€™; and could follow a present, Ï‡Ïá½µ, no less than Ï‡Ïá¿†Î½ (cp. Ant. 666).â€” Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½ â€¦ á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚: cp. Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î±Î½Î¿á¿¦ÏÎ³Î¿Î½, equiv. in sense to Î¿á¼± Ï€Î±Î½Î¿á¿¦ÏÎ³Î¿Î¹: cp. 972 n.: Thuc. 1. 13Ï„á½¸ Î»á¿ƒÏƒÏ„Î¹Îºá½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¸á¿„ÏÎ¿Ï…Î½.â€” Shakesp. Nicephorus VasilÃ¡kes (Î’Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»á½±ÎºÎ·Ï‚), a professor of rhetoric at Constantinople in the latter part of the twelfth century, places these three verses of Sophocles at the head of a short piece in his rhetorical â€˜Exercisesâ€™ (Î ÏÎ¿Î³Ï…Î¼Î½á½±ÏƒÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±), and makes them the text of a discourse evidently prompted by the evils of his own time. The verses remind us, he says, how well Sophocles understood the function of Tragedy as a ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½´ Ï€Î±Î¹Î´Î±Î³Ï‰Î³á½·Î±, or vehicle of moral teaching. After setting forth in action the warning example of Aegisthus, the poet here á¼€Ï€Î¿Î´á½·Î´Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ Î¾Ï…Î½á¾´Î´Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Îµá¼°ÏÎ³Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚, i.e., generalises the lesson. From a literary and aesthetic point of view the remark deserves the notice of those who, like Dindorf, think the verses spurious. If the speech of Orestes ended with v. 1504, the effect would manifestly be too abrupt.

á½ˆÏ. Î¼á½´ Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½–Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ á¼¡Î´Î¿Î½á½´Î½

The imperf. Ï‡Ïá¿†Î½, with Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹, implies that, though it ought to be so, it is not. The sense is, in substance, what might be expressed by a conditional sentence, á¼¥Î´Îµ Î´á½·ÎºÎ· á¼¦Î½ á¼‚Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½, Îµá¼° Ï„á½¸ Îµá¼°Îºá½¸Ï‚ á¼”Ï€Î±Î¸Î¿Î½.

Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚, immediately after the crime in each case; Aegisthus has enjoyed too long an impunity. Cp. 13 f.n.

Î¸á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹ is better here than Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î¹, since it suggests more clearly the reference to the actual case of Aegisthus. The optative is, however, also tenable. Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ Î³Îµ: Î³Îµ emphasises, not Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½, but rather the whole sentence, and might have immediately followed á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚, if metre had allowed: cp. Nicephorus VasilÃ¡kes (Î’Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»á½±ÎºÎ·Ï‚), a professor of rhetoric at Constantinople in the latter part of the twelfth century, places these three verses of Sophocles at the head of a short piece in his rhetorical â€˜Exercisesâ€™ (Î ÏÎ¿Î³Ï…Î¼Î½á½±ÏƒÎ¼Î±Ï„Î±), and makes them the text of a discourse evidently prompted by the evils of his own time. The verses remind us, he says, how well Sophocles understood the function of Tragedy as a ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½´ Ï€Î±Î¹Î´Î±Î³Ï‰Î³á½·Î±, or vehicle of moral teaching. After setting forth in action the warning example of Aegisthus, the poet here á¼€Ï€Î¿Î´á½·Î´Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ Î¾Ï…Î½á¾´Î´Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Îµá¼°ÏÎ³Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚, i.e., generalises the lesson. From a literary and aesthetic point of view the remark deserves the notice of those who, like Dindorf, think the verses spurious. If the speech of Orestes ended with v. 1504, the effect would manifestly be too abrupt.

Î´á¼° á¼Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸ÎµÏá½·Î±Ï‚ â€¦ á¼Î¾á¿†Î»Î¸ÎµÏ‚, come forth in freedom. For Î´Î¹á½± denoting the state, cp. Thuc. 6. 34Â§ 2 á¼€Îµá½¶ Î´Î¹á½° Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Ï… Îµá¼°Ïƒá½·. Both Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î¿á¿¦Î½ and Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÎ¿á¿¦Î½ (as Ï„á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ and Ï„á½³Î»ÎµÎ¿Ï‚) were Attic, while the forms without Î¹ are alone used by Herodotus.

This play contains no presage of trouble to come, and fitly ends with the word Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ‰Î¸á½³Î½. Contrast the closing words of the Choephori (1075 f.): Ï€Î¿á¿– Î´á¿†Ï„Î± ÎºÏÎ±Î½Îµá¿–, Ï€Î¿á¿– ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î»á½µÎ¾ÎµÎ¹ | Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î¹ÏƒÎ¸á½²Î½ Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï„Î·Ï‚;
